definition: Of or pertaining to Lombardy, or the inhabitants of Lombardy.

The only existing genus of Merostomata. It includes only a fewspecies from the East Indies, and one (Limulus polyphemus) from theAtlantic coast of North America. Called also Molucca crab, king crab,horseshoe crab, and horsefoot.
One of the Longirostres.
Crystallized litharge, obtained by fusion in the form of fineyellow scales.
One of the followers of Lucifer, bishop of Cagliari, in thefourth century, who separated from the orthodox churches because theywould not go as far as he did in opposing the Arians.
Muddy; slimy; thick. Sir T. Browne.
Lubric.
A bitter, white, crystalline substance found in orange andlemon seeds.
Like wood.

Having length; rather long or too long; prolix; not brief; --said chiefly of discourses, writings, and the like. "Lengthyperiods." Washington. "Some lengthy additions." Byron. "These wouldbe details too lengthy." Jefferson. "To cut short lengthyexplanations." Trench.
Same as Ligan. Brande & C.
Linear. Holland.
A larva.
One of a series of anhydrides of an amido type, analogous tothe lactones, as oxindol.
Any one of several species of small arctic rodents of thegenera Myodes and Cuniculus, resembling the meadow mice in form. Theyare found in both hemispheres.

The connection between sovereign and subject by which they weremutually bound, the former to protection and the securing of justice,the latter to faithful service; allegiance. [Written also ligeancyand liegance.] Chaucer.
Lobiped.
A vessel used to receive the washings of ores of metals.
To tear; to rend; to separate by tearing; to mangle; as, tolacerate the flesh. Hence: To afflict; to torture; as, to laceratethe heart.

A cutaneous disease which first appears as blebs or as reddish,shining, slightly prominent spots, with spreading edges. These areoften followed by an eruption of dark or yellowish prominent nodules,frequently producing great deformity. In one variety of the disease,anæsthesia of the skin is a prominent symptom. In addition there maybe wasting of the muscles, falling out of the hair and nails, anddistortion of the hands and feet with destruction of the bones andjoints. It is incurable, and is probably contagious.Mycobacteriumleprae, curable in most cases by therapy with a combination ofantibiotics, but cases resistant to therapy are increasing.
Pertaining to, or characteristic of, the Lyencephala.
Of or pertaining to the lochia.
The tendency or disposition to represent objects faithfully,without abstraction, conventionalities, or idealization.
The occupation and holding of a position, as by a besiegingparty; an instrument thrown up in a captured position; as, to effecta lodgment.
Pertaining to the formation of uric-acid concretions (stone) inthe bladder and other parts of the body; as, lithic diathesis. LIthicacid (Old Med. Chem.), uric acid. See Uric acid, under Uric.
See 2d Loch.
To express or feel sorrow; to weep or wail; to mourn.Jeremiah lamented for Josiah. 2 Chron. xxxv. 25.Ye shall weep and lament, but the world shall rejoice. John xvi. 20.
An unfermentable carbohydrate obtained by gently heatinglevulose.
A curve or arch in a bit to afford room for the tongue of thehorse.
Of or pertaining to the Gull family (Laridæ).
Sap green. [China]
. A stable where horses are kept for hire, and where stablingis provided. See Livery, n., 3 (e) (f) & (g).
Given to luxury; voluptuous. [Obs.]

Either one of two species of wading birds of the genus Aramus,intermediate between the cranes and rails. The limpkins areremarkable for the great length of the toes. One species (A.giganteus) inhabits Florida and the West Indies; the other (A.scolopaceus) is found in South America. Called also courlan, andcrying bird.
Weary of living. Shak.
To convert into stone or stony material; to petrify.
A name formerly given in Pennsylvania, Maryland, and Virginiato the Spanish real of one eight of a dollar (or 12
A frolic; a jolly time. [Colloq.] Dickens.
The act of loosening or slackening, or the state of beingloosened or slackened.

A cement of clay or other tenacious infusible substance forsealing joints in apparatus, or the mouths of vessels or tubes, orfor coating the bodies of retorts, etc., when exposed to heat; --called also luting.
A sterile transformed stamen.
See Lamella.
An alkaloid extracted from hops as a colorless volatile liquid.
One who loses by sloth or neglect; a worthless person; a lorel.[Archaic] Spenser.One sad losel soils a name for aye. Byron.
A group of rodents, including the hares. They have fourincisors in the upper jaw. Called also Duplicidentata.

Moderately warm; neither cold nor hot; tepid; not ardent; notzealous; cool; indifferent. " Lukewarm blood." Spenser. " Lukewarmpatriots." Addison.An obedience so lukewarm and languishing that it merits not the nameof passion. Dryden.-- Luce"warm`ly, adv.-- Luce"warm`ness, n.
of Lose. Chaucer.
A licensing. [R.]
Spirits or ghosts of the departed; specters.The Lars and Lemures moan with midnight plaint. Milton.
Lenticel.
See Lute, a cement.
Pertaining to, or derived from, the juice of the Lactucavirosa; -- said of certain acids.

A large North American tree of the genus Robinia (R.Pseudacacia), producing large slender racemes of white, fragrant,papilionaceous flowers, and often cultivated as an ornamental tree.In England it is called acacia.
An alembic; a still. [Obs.] Spenser. Shak.
A sudden thrust or pass, as with a sword.
One versed in liturgiology.
A little lake. Southey.
Capable of being levigated.
Pleasant; jocose. [R.]The joyous and lepid consul. Sydney Smith.
A kind of eruption upon the skin; lentigo; freckle.
See Lodgment.
A thong by which a dog is led; a leash. Halliwell.
One who makes a list or roll.
State of being literate.
Of or pertaining to the larynx; adapted to operations on thelarynx; as, laryngeal forceps.
A condition in which uric (lithic) acid is present in theblood.
Flax. See Linen. [Obs.]
Of or pertaining to the spleen and intestine; as, the lieno-intestinal vein of the frog.

A personal satire in writing; usually, malicious and abusivecensure written only to reproach and distress.Like her who missed her name in a lampoon, And grieved to findherself decayed so soon. Dryden.

That part of a human being or quadruped, which extends oneither side of the spinal column between the hip bone and the falseribs. In human beings the loins are also called the reins. SeeIllust. of Beef.

To delay; to loiter; to remain or wait long; to be slow orreluctant in parting or moving; to be slow in deciding; to be insuspense; to hesitate.Nor cast one longing, lingering look behind. Gray.Perhaps thou linger'st, in deep thoughts detained. Milton.
A devourer or absorber of money. "Law is a lickpenny." Sir W.Scott.
A plant (Sedum Telephium) with fleshy leaves, which has extremepowers of resisting drought; garden ox-pine.
Flimsy; vague; deceptive. [Obs.] Ascham.
In a lithe, pliant, or flexible manner.
Any plant of the Lily family or order. Lindley.
Light from a lamp.This world's artificial lamplights. Owen Meredith.
Of or pertaining to lexigraphy.
Free from grief or anxiety; gay; cheerful; merry.-- Light"-heart`ed*ly, adv.-- Light"-heart"ed*ness, n.
A genus of cephalopods, including numerous species of squids,common on the coasts of America and Europe. They are much used forfish bait.
Furnished or built with short studs; as, a low-studded house orroom.
Pine wood abounding in pitch, used for torches in the SouthernUnited States; pine knots, dry sticks, and the like, for kindling afire quickly or making a blaze.
Malignity. [P.] Burton.
A hypothetical land, or continent, supposed by some to haveexisted formerly in the Indian Ocean, of which Madagascar is aremnant. Herschel.
A part of a book or literary composition printed and deliveredby itself; a number; a part.
Having the character of larceny; as, a larcenous act;committing larceny. "The larcenous and burglarious world." SydneySmith.-- Lar"ce*nous*ly, adv.
A lace. See Lace. [Obs.] Chaucer.
In a labored manner; with labor.
A female lion.
The spongelike fibers of the fruit of a cucurbitaceous plant(Luffa Ægyptiaca); called also vegetable sponge.
Compar. of Low, a.
Pertaining to, or used for, purification.
Such as can be lent; available for lending; as, loanable funds;-- used mostly in financial business and writings.
See Leger, n., 2. [Obs.] Shak.
Not placing a high estimate on ecclesiastical organizations orforms; -- applied especially to Episcopalians, and opposed to high-church. See High Church, under High.
Having a color like liver; dark reddish brown.
See Lack. [Obs.] Chaucer.

A small European bird of the Plover family (Vanellus cristatus,or V. vanellus). It has long and broad wings, and is noted for itsrapid, irregular fight, upwards, downwards, and in circles. Its backis coppery or greenish bronze. Its eggs are the "plover's eggs" ofthe London market, esteemed a delicacy. It is called also peewit,dastard plover, and wype. The gray lapwing is the Squatarola cinerea.
Luxated. [Obs.]
To put out of joint; to luxate. [Obs.]
Limber. [Obs.] Holland.
To beat against the wind; to tack. [Obs.] Dryden.
To release from restraint or bondage; to set at liberty; tofree; to manumit; to disengage; as, to liberate a slave or prisoner;to liberate the mind from prejudice; to liberate gases.

A leguminous plant of the genus Lupinus, especially L. albus,the seeds of which have been used for food from ancient times. Thecommon species of the Eastern United States is L. perennis. There aremany species in California.
A kind of pudding or sausage made of liver or pork. [Obs.]Chapman.
Sportive; ridiculous; wanton. [Obs.] Tooker.

Imparting power; having motion; as, the live spindle of alathe. Live birth, the condition of being born in such a state thatacts of life are manifested after the extrusion of the whole body.Dunglison.-- Live box, a cell for holding living objects under microscopicalexamination. P. H. Gosse.-- Live feathers, feathers which have been plucked from the livingbird, and are therefore stronger and more elastic.-- Live gang. (Sawing) See under Gang.-- Live grass (Bot.), a grass of the genus Eragrostis.-- Live load (Engin.), a suddenly applied load; a varying load; amoving load; as a moving train of cars on a bridge, or wind pressureon a roof. Live oak (Bot.), a species of oak (Quercus virens),growing in the Southern States, of great durability, and highlyesteemed for ship timber. In California the Q. chrysolepis and someother species are also called live oaks.-- Live ring (Engin.), a circular train of rollers upon which aswing bridge, or turntable, rests, and which travels around acircular track when the bridge or table turns.-- Live steam , steam direct from the boiler, used for any purpose,in distinction from exhaust steam.-- Live stock, horses, cattle, and other domestic animals kept on afarm. whole body.
A native or inhabitant of the Lowlands, especially of theLowlands of Scotland, as distinguished from Highlander.
A woman whose employment is laundering.
A lark. [Scot.]
One who looks. Looker-on, a spectator; one that looks on, buthas no agency or part in an affair.Did not this fatal war affront thy coast, Yet sattest thou an idlelooker-on Fairfax.
Learning; lesson; lore. [Obs.] Spenser.
A coarse perennial grass of several species of Elymus, esp. E.Canadensis, and the European E. arenarius.
A sweetheart or mistress.
In a loyal manner; faithfully.
One who libels. [Written also libeller.] " Libelers of others."Buckkminster.
To affect with leprosy.
A poisonous narcotic alkaloid extracted from the leaves ofIndian tobacco (Lobelia inflata) as a yellow oil, having atobaccolike taste and odor.
Manner of linking or of being linked; -- said of the union ofatoms or radicals in the molecule.

Any one of several species of parasitic nematoid worms whichinfest the lungs and air passages of cattle, sheep, and otheranimals, often proving fatal. The lungworm of cattle (Strongylusmicrurus) and that of sheep (S. filaria) are the best known.
To tie with a ligature; to bind around; to bandage.
of Leap. leaped.
The produce of animals yielding milk; milk and that which ismade from it.
A leafy shelter; a place covered with foliage. [Obs.]Behind the mill, under a levesel. Chaucer.
A small lobe; a subdivision of a lobe. Lobule of the ear.(Anat.) Same as Lobe of the ear.
Same as Lepadoid.
In a liquid manner; flowingly.
Of or relating to the cell or compartment of an ovary, etc.; incomposition, having cells; as trilocular. Gray.
Any one of the numerous species of reptiles belonging to theorder Lacertilia; sometimes, also applied to reptiles of otherorders, as the Hatteria.
A peculiar amyloid substance, colored blue by iodine andsulphuric acid, occurring mainly as an abnormal infiltration into thespleen, liver, etc.
In the manner of the Latin language; in correct Latin. [Obs.]Heylin.
In a languishing manner; pathetically.
Gluttony; gormandizing. [Obs.]
A lover. [Obs.] Chaucer.
An allowance of a certain rate per cent for the leaking ofcasks, or waste of liquors by leaking.
To transfer (the molten glass) from the pot to the formingtable.
Filings of metal. [Obs.] "An ounce . . . of silver lymaille."Chaucer.

A genus of wingless thysanurous insects having an elongatedflattened body, covered with shining scales and terminated by sevenunequal bristles. A common species (Lepisma saccharina) is found inhouses, and often injures books and furniture. Called also shiner,silver witch, silver moth, and furniture bug.
The calling sound made by cows and other bovine animals.
Pertaining to both larynx and trachea; as, the laryngotrachealcartilage in the frog.
Loathsome. [Obs.] Spenser.
Any species of Pedicularis, a genus of perennial herbs. It wassaid to make sheep that fed on it lousy. Yellow lousewort , a plantof the genus Rhinanthus.
Of or pertaining to lamella or to lamellæ; lamellar.
Of or pertaining to a legislator or legislature.
A grayish brown limestone, containing fossil shells, whichreflect a beautiful play of colors. It is also called fire marble,from its fiery reflections.
One who adheres to the letter or exact word; an interpreteraccording to the letter.
To wash; to bathe; as, to lave a bruise.His feet the foremost breakers lave. Byron.
A landscape. [Obs. except in poetry.]Straight my eye hath caught new pleasures, Whilst the landskip roundit measures. Milton.

The triturating apparatus in the stomach of a lobster; -- socalled from a fancied resemblance to a seated female figure. Itconsists of calcareous plates. Ladies' man, a man who affects thesociety of ladies.-- Lady altar, an altar in a lady chapel. Shipley.-- Lady chapel, a chapel dedicated to the Virgin Mary.-- Lady court, the court of a lady of the manor.-- Lady crab (Zoöl.), a handsomely spotted swimming crab(Platyonichus ocellatus) very common on the sandy shores of theAtlantic coast of the United States.-- Lady fern. (Bot.) See Female fern, under Female, and Illust. ofFern.-- Lady in waiting, a lady of the queen's household, appointed towait upon or attend the queen.-- Lady Mass, a Mass said in honor of the Virgin Mary. Shipley. Ladyof the manor, a lady having jurisdiction of a manor; also, the wifeof a manor lord. Lady's maid, a maidservant who dresses and waitsupon a lady. Thackeray.-- Our Lady, the Virgin Mary.
Systematized knowledge of the action and functions of thelarynx; in pathology, the department which treats of the diseases ofthe larynx.
To set sail. [Obs.] Acts xiii. 13.
That which loosens; -- esp., a muscle which by its contractionloosens some part.
Moderately warm; not hot; tepid.-- Luke"ness, n. [Obs.]Nine penn'orth o'brandy and water luke. Dickens.

Exuberant in growth; rank; excessive; very abundant; as, aluxuriant growth of grass; luxuriant foliage.Prune the luxuriant, the uncouth refine. Pope.Luxuriant flower (Bot.), one in which the floral envelopes areoverdeveloped at the expense of the essential organs.
A genus of free-swimming macruran Crustacea, having a slenderbody and long appendages.
Limpidity. [Obs.]
The small, whitish brown fruit of an East Indian tree (Lansiumdomesticum). It has a fleshy pulp, with an agreeable subacid taste.Balfour.
Having large hands, Fig.: Taking, or giving, in largequantities; rapacious or bountiful.
One of the small nodules sometimes found in the neighborhood ofthe spleen; an accessory or supplementary spleen.
of Leave. Chaucer.
A quantity sufficient to fill a ladle.
A sailor on his first voyage.
Producing or containing lignite; lignitic.
One who labels. [Written also labeller.]

One of the shooting stars which constitute the star shower thatrecurs near the fourteenth of November at intervals of about thirty-three years; so called because shooting stars appear on the heavensto move in lines directed from the constellation Leo.
A large marine annelid (Nephthys cæca), inhabiting the sandyshores of Europe and America. It is whitish, with a pearly luster,and grows to the length of eight or ten inches.
Living a long time; of great age. Sir T. Browne.
Tape or braid; an ornament. Halliwell. Leere side, the leftside, as that on which a leere or ornament was worn. B. Jonson.
Bounded by a distinct line.
Shining; bright; resplendent. " The sun's lucent orb." Milton.
The act of deriding.
An instrument for estimating the amount of cream contained inmilk by ascertaining its relative opacity.
Rotation in the direction of an outgoing right-handed screw;counter-clockwise rotation; -- applied chiefly to the turning of theplane of polarization of light.
A dropsical habit of body, or the commencement of anasarca;paleness, with viscid juices and cold sweats.
See Levulose.
A legislator; a lawgiver.
An instrument for crushing stones in the bladder.

The state or quality of being loyal; fidelity to a superior, orto duty, love, etc.He had such loyalty to the king as the law required. Clarendon.Not withstanding all the subtle bait With which those Amazons hislove still craved, To his one love his loyalty he saved. Spenser.
Inflammation of the laminæ or fleshy plates along the coffinbone of a horse; founder. Youatt.
A band of white matter in the wall of fourth ventricle of thebrain.
The quality or state of being large.
A nonsense poem of five anapestic lines, of which  lines 1, 2,and 5 are of there feet, and rime, and lines 3 and 4 are of two feet,and rime; as --
A guillemot. [Written also longie.] [Prov. Eng. & Scot.] Sir W.Scott.
A substance of a strongly marked yellow color, extracted fromthe yelk of eggs, and from the tissue of the corpus luteum.
A preparation of casein from milk, used in printing calico.
Such as can be litigated.
The operation of breaking a stone in the bladder into smallpieces capable of being voided.
A lingerer; a dull, drowsy fellow. [Obs.]
Same as Lief.
A painter; an artist; esp.:(a) One who paints portraits.(b) One who illuminates books. [Archaic]
A yellowish green resin from Lobelia, used as an emetic anddiaphoretic.
Muddy; turbid; thick. [Obs.]
The state or quality of being a lady; the personality of alady.
A husband's brother; -- used in reference to leviratemarriages.
Act or state of lying hid, or lurking. [R.] Sir T. Browne.
Tongued; having the tongue visible.Lions . . . represented as armed and langued gules. Cussans.
In an even or level manner.
To make local; to fix in, or assign to, a definite place. H.Spencer. Wordsworth.
A superior quality of Turkish smoking tobacco, so called fromthe place where produced, the ancient Laodicea.
A small iron rod which suspends the core of the mold in castinga shell.
An assistant to a corporal; a private performing the duties ofa corporal; -- called also lance corporal.
A confused heap; a throng, as of persons; a jumble, as ofsounds. [Obs.]To turn prayer into a kind of lurry. Milton.
See Granulite.
The linden. See Linden. Chaucer.
A laggard.
An a lame, crippled, disabled, or imperfect manner; as, to walklamely; a figure lamely drawn.
A genus of acalephs, having a bell-shaped body with eightgroups of short tentacles around the margin. It attaches itself by asucker at the base of the pedicel.
Urine. See Lant. [Obs.]
Containing, or like, lymph.
See Ladykin.
A brick or tile. Knight.
A discharge of a white, yellowish, or greenish, viscid mucus,resulting from inflammation or irritation of the membrane lining thegenital organs of the female; the whites. Dunglison.
Lying at, or extending toward, the side; away from the mesialplane; external; -- opposed to mesial.
With slightly overlapping borders; -- said of a suture.
Lying hid; concealed; latent. [R.]
One skilled in the laws; a writer on law. Milman. J. Morley.
Turning or rotating the plane of polarization towards the left;levogyrate, as levulose, left handed quartz crystals, etc. [Writtenalso lævorotatory.]
Dear. See Lief. [Obs.] Chaucer.
The leavings or dung of beasts.
Having the form of a lichen.
A linctus. [Obs.] Fuller.
A genus of small spiral pteropods, common in the Arctic andAntarctic seas. It contributes to the food of the right whales.
An Asiatic sardine (Clupea Neohowii), valued for its oil.
Using a noose, as a gladiator. [Obs. or R.]Retiary and laqueary combatants. Sir T. Browne.
Libation. [Obs.] Holland.
One who, or that which, lulls.
A kind of light vessel used on the coast of China, having thehull built on a European model, and the rigging like that of aChinese junk. Admiral Foote.
A rheumatic pain in the loins and the small of the back.
See Lycanthropy, 2.
Of or pertaining to the Longipennes; longipennate.
Pertaining to tidal movements dependent on the moon. Bache.Lunitidal interval. See Retard, n.
The state or quality of being leprous or scaly; also, a scale.Bacon.
The twin flower which grows in cold northern climates.
Of or pertaining to Lapland, or the Lapps.-- n.
Having a long life; having constitutional peculiarities whichmake long life probable; lasting long; as, a long-lived tree; theyare a longlived family; long-lived prejudices.
A book of the Old Testament attributed to the prophet Jeremiah,and taking its name from the nature of its contents.
Fitted to excite laughter; as, a laughable story; a laughablescene.

Any one of two or three species of Australian birds of thegenus Menura. The male is remarkable for having the sixteen tailfeathers very long and, when spread, arranged in the form of a lyre.The common lyre bird (Menura superba), inhabiting New South Wales, isabout the size of a grouse. Its general color is brown, with rufouscolor on the throat, wings, tail coverts and tail. Called also lyrepheasant and lyre-tail.
To weaken or impair. [R.]
In a lusty or vigorous manner.
Same as Low side window, under Low, a.
A quaternary deposit, usually consisting of a fine yellowishearth, on the banks of the Rhine and other large rivers.
See Lachrymatory, n., and Lachrymal, a.
Marked with little lines.
To use words or phrases borrowed from the Latin. Dryden.
An order of brachiopods, in which the valves of shell are notarticulated by a hinge. It includes the Lingula, Discina, and alliedforms. [Written also Lyopoma.]
The quality of being leaky.
Lacerating or tearing; as, the laniary canine teeth.
An attracting of attention, as a lion; also, the treating orregarding as a lion.

The unlawful taking and carrying away of things personal withintent to deprive the right owner of the same; theft. Cf.Embezzlement. Grand larceny and Petit larceny are distinctions havingreference to the nature or value of the property stolen. They areabolished in England.-- Mixed, or Compound, larceny, that which, under statute, includesin it the aggravation of a taking from a building or the person.-- Simple larceny, that which is not accompanied with anyaggravating circumstances.
One who has but a smattering of Latin. Walker.
A dormer window. See Dormer.
A small branching shrub (Dirca palustris), with a white, softwood, and a tough, leathery bark, common in damp woods in theNorthern United States; -- called also moosewood, and wicopy. Gray.
The season of Lenten or Lent.
Composed by candlelight, or by night; of or pertaining to nightstudies; laborious or painstaking. Pope.
An esculent swallow.
The course and distance made by a vessel on one tack or betweentacks.
Forbearance to punish or resent.
A person infected with a filthy or pestilential disease; aleper. Chaucer.Like loathsome lazars, by the hedges lay. Spenser.Lazar house a lazaretto; also, a hospital for quarantine.
A group of lamellicorn, plant-eating beetles; -- called alsoLamellicornes.
A person who waits at the mouth of the shaft to receive thekibble of ore.
The quality of being lingual.
See Liquidambar.
A stone for the lap, on which shoemakers beat leather.
The line drawn through a focus of a conic section parallel tothe directrix and terminated both ways by the curve. It is theparameter of the principal axis. See Focus, and Parameter.
In a lacteous manner; after the manner of milk.

Any one of several species of fringilline birds of the genusCalcarius (or Plectrophanes), and allied genera. The Lapland longspur(C. Lapponicus), the chestnut-colored longspur (C. ornatus), andother species, inhabit the United States.
To lie; to tell lies. [Obs.]
Resembling the moon in shape.
A dog used in hunting the wild boar; a leamer. Spenser.
See Lustihood. [Obs.] Chaucer.
Pertaining to, or resembling, a labyrinth; intricate;labyrinthian.
The act of raising; elevation; upward motion, as that producedby the action of a levator muscle.
A genus of coniferous trees, having deciduous leaves, infascicles (see Illust. of Fascicle).
A projecting piece to which anything, as a rod, is attached, oragainst which anything, as a wedge or key, bears, or through which abolt passes, etc.
See Lignin.
A little hollow; a loculus.
Such as can be lost.
The clothing (esp., an outer, wooden covering), as of a steamcylinder, applied to prevent the radiation of heat; a covering oflags; -- called also deading and cleading.
A nymph of the meadows; -- called also Limniad.
A lace. See Lace. [Obs.] Chaucer.
To inclose, or nearly inclose, as a harbor or a vessel, withland.
See Lanier. [Obs.] Chaucer.
Same as Levorotatory. Cf. Dextrorotatory.
A small leguminous tree (Cytisus Laburnum), native of the Alps.The plant is reputed to be poisonous, esp. the bark and seeds. It hashandsome racemes of yellow blossoms.
An awkward, clumsy fellow; a lubber. Swift.
A kind of crystallite having a (slender) acicular form.
Beset with snares; insnared, as with birdlime. L. Addison.
See Lithochromics.
An igneous rock consisting largely of chrysolite, with pyroxeneand picotite (a variety of spinel containing chromium).
A barrulet, or, rarely, a bendlet, with pendants, or points,usually three, especially used as a mark of cadency to distinguish aneldest or only son while his father is still living.
Producing lenticels; dotted with lenticels.
A dog held by a leam.
A union, or bond of union; an intimacy; especially, an illicitintimacy between a man and a woman.
A long, narrow spade for stony lands.
The shafts or thills of a wagon or carriage. [Prov. Eng.]
One who makes a lipogram.

That which is lugged; anything cumbrous and heavy to becarried; especially, a traveler's trunks, baggage, etc., or theircontents.I am gathering up my luggage, and preparing for my journey. Swift.What do you mean, To dote thus on such luggage! Shak.
of Lead, to guide Chaucer.

A heavy, clumsy, or awkward fellow; a sturdy drone; a clown.Lingering lubbers lose many a penny. Tusser.Land lubber, a name given in contempt by sailors to a person wholives on land.-- Lubber grasshopper (Zoöl.), a large, stout, clumsy grasshopper;esp., Brachystola magna, from the Rocky Mountain plains, and Romaleamicroptera, which is injurious to orange trees in Florida.-- Lubber's hole (Naut.), a hole in the floor of the "top," next themast, through which sailors may go aloft without going over the rimby the futtock shrouds. It is considered by seamen as only fit to beused by lubbers. Totten.-- Lubber's line, point, or mark, a line or point in the compasscase indicating the head of the ship, and consequently the coursewhich the ship is steering.
The operation of cutting into the larynx, from the outside ofthe neck, for assisting respiration when obstructed, or for removingforeign bodies.
One who longs for anything.
Law; as, lex talionis, the law of retaliation; lex terræ, thelaw of the land; lex fori, the law of the forum or court; lex loci,the law of the place; lex mercatoria, the law or custom of merchants.
slender or narrow; -- said of type the letters of which havethin lines, or are unusually narrow in proportion to their height. W.Savage.
The broad-billed singing birds, such as the swallows, and theirallies.
Any fish belonging to the Dipnoi; -- so called because theyhave both lungs and gills.
A gum resin gathered from certain Oriental species of Cistus.It has a pungent odor and is chiefly used in making plasters, and forfumigation. [Written also labdanum.]
A curve of the fourth degree, invented by Pascal. Its polarequation is r = a cos + b.
Belonging to the seashore or a seaport; along and on the shore."Longshore thieves." R. Browning.
Generating or shedding tears; given to shedding tears; suffusedwith tears; tearful.You should have seen his lachrymose visnomy. Lamb.-- Lach"ry*mose`ly, adv.
A guillemot; -- called also lavy. [Prov. Eng.]
A peculiar genus of rotifers, remarkable for the absence ofciliated disks. By some zoölogists it is thought to be like theancestral form of the Arthropoda.
Dexterous in taking and conveying away; thievish; pilfering;addicted to petty thefts. Fuller.
A kind of erratic melancholy, in which the patient imagineshimself a wolf, and imitates the actions of that animal.
A pointed wooden tool used in glazing leaden lattice.
A place where persons under arrest are temporarily locked up; awatchhouse.
The cell of a pericarp in which the seed is lodged.
One who laments.
The act of lubricating; the act of making slippery.
In a loud manner. Denham.
Shining; brilliant. [Obs.] "Lamping eyes." Spenser.
A place for storing wool.
Like or pertaining to the lemurs or the Lemuroidea.-- n.
In a luxuriant manner.
Plaintive; -- a term applied to a mournful or pathetic movementor style. Moore.
Logarithmically.
See Litmus.
A mineral of pale steel-gray color and metallic luster,occurring in isometric crystals, and also massive. It is a sulphideof cobalt containing some nickel or copper.
A genus of fossil trees of the Devonian and Carboniferous ages,having the exterior marked with scars, mostly in quincunx order,produced by the separation of the leafstalks.
See Leze majesty.
of Lie, v. i.
See Langrage.
Confined to a fresh-water lake by reason of waterfalls or dams;-- said of fishes that would naturally seek the sea, after spawning;as, the landlocked salmon.
An old name of loo (a).
A high explosive consisting principally of picric acid, used asa shell explosive in the British service; -- so named from theproving grounds at Lydd, England.
Consisting of, or covered with, laminæ, or thin plates, scales,or layers, one over another; laminated.
Lumpish. [Obs.] Spenser.
Inclined in mind to low or unworthy things; showing a basemind.Low-minded and immoral. Macaulay.All old religious jealousies were condemned as low-mindedinfirmities. Bancroft.
Loathsome. [Obs.] " Loathly mouth." Spenser.
A cooling periodical wind in the Isle of Cyprus, blowing fromthe northwest from eight o'clock, A. M., to the middle of the day orlater.
A post (generally a pillar of iron) supporting a lamp orlantern for lighting a street, park, etc.
See Lake dwellers, under Lake.
A support for the back, attached to the seat of a carriage.[Colloq.]
Having a large or generous heart or disposition; noble;liberal.-- Large"-heart`ed*ness, n.
Lightning. [Obs.]Wild thunder dint and fiery leven. Chaucer.
Made of leather; consisting of. leather; as, a leathern purse."A leathern girdle about his loins." Matt. iii. 4.
Long duration of life; length of life.The instances of longevity are chiefly amongst the abstemious.Arbuthnot.
Having a general resemblance to lilies or to liliaceous plants.
A popular name for any society or club which meets for thepractice of male part songs.

Of or pertaining to Lombardy of the Lombards. Lombardicalphabet, the ancient alphabet derived from the Roman, and employedin the manuscript of Italy.-- Lombardic architecture, the debased Roman style of architectureas found in parts of Northern Italy. F. G. Lee. Lombardy poplar.(Bot.) See Poplar.
See Ligeance.
The inspissated juice of the common lettuce, sometimes used asa substitute for opium.
See Logan.
A monster capable of assuming a woman's form, who was said todevour human beings or suck their blood; a vampire; a sorceress; awith.
Having the form of the tongue; tongue-shaped.
Of or pertaining to the Labyrinthici.-- n.
Petrified wood. [Obs.]
A dragon fly.
The act or process of lapidifying; fossilization; petrifaction.
To grow fat. [Obs.]
The lark. [Old Eng. & Scot.] [Written also lavrock.] Gower.
To make antiseptic.
One who labors in a toilsome occupation; a person who does workthat requires strength rather than skill, as distinguished from thatof an artisan.
A ravenous appetite caused by disease; excessive and morbidhunger.
Inhabiting the seashore, esp. the zone between high-water andlow-water mark.
The whelp of a lioness; a young lion.
One who learns; a scholar.
A colorless substance isomeric with chlorophyll, contained inparts of plants capable of becoming green. Watts.
Involving a limit; as, a limitive law, one designed to limitexisting powers. [R.]
Lipic.
Of, pertaining to, or resembling, lichens; abounding inlichens; covered with lichens. G. Eliot.
A complex, nitrogenous phosphorized substance widelydistributed through the animal body, and especially conspicuous inthe brain and nerve tissue, in yolk of eggs, and in the white bloodcorpuscles.
A division of reptiles, including the serpents and lizards; thePlagiotremata.
Having long legs. Thackeray.
An engraving on a gem.
of Lead, to guide. Chaucer.
Lamentation.Lamentings heard i' the air. Shak.
An ingot. [Written also lingot.]

Having a license; permitted or authorized by license; as, alicensed victualer; a licensed traffic. Licensed victualer, one whohas a license to keep an in or eating house; esp., a victualer whohas a license to sell intoxicating liquors.
. Same as Leuco-.
One given to luxury. [Obs.] Sir W. Temple.
Lean. [Obs.] Spenser.
One who leads a dance.[Obs.] B. Jonson.
One who lies down; one who rests or remains, as in concealment.There were liers in a ambush against him. Josh. viii. 14.
Made less harsh or burdensome; alleviated. [Obs.] Sir. T.Elyot.
A yellow dyestuff obtained from the foliage of the dyer's broom(Reseda luteola).
Like or pertaining to the Lepisma.
The quality of being lethal; mortality.
In a lengthy manner; at great length or extent.
See Syringin.
A person affected with leprosy.
The stilt.
A disk which surrounds the mouth and bears the tentacles of theBryozoa. See Phylactolemata.
A lode; a limited mass of rock bearing valuable mineral.
Covered with a lid. Keats.
A dull, stupid fellow; a drone. [Obs.] Spenser.

One of the edges of the aperture of a univalve shell. Lip bit,a pod auger. See Auger.-- Lip comfort, comfort that is given with words only.-- Lip comforter, one who comforts with words only.-- Lip labor, unfelt or insincere speech; hypocrisy. Bale.-- Lip reading, the catching of the words or meaning of one speakingby watching the motion of his lips without hearing his voice.Carpenter.-- Lip salve, a salve for sore lips.-- Lip service, expression by the lips of obedience and devotionwithout the performance of acts suitable to such sentiments.-- Lip wisdom, wise talk without practice, or unsupported byexperience.-- Lip work. (a) Talk. (b) Kissing. [Humorous] B. Jonson.-- Lip make a lip, to drop the under lip in sullenness or contempt.Shak.-- To shoot out the lip (Script.), to show contempt by protrudingthe lip.
consisting of, containing, or characterized by, laterite; as,lateritic formations.
A salt of lauric acid.
The office of a lecturer.
Liquorice. [Obs.] Chaucer.
Companion for life. Hawthorne.
The worship of a stone or stones.

To make legitimate, lawful, or valid; esp., to put in theposition or state of a legitimate person before the law, by legalmeans; as, to legitimate a bastard child.To enact a statute of that which he dares not seem to approve, evento legitimate vice. Milton.
A broad-leafed fossil alga.
Containing the latex; -- applied to the tissue or tubularvessels in which the latex of the plant is found.
With respect to place; in place; as, to be locally separated ordistant.
Liberal principles; the principles and methods of the liberalsin politics or religion; specifically, the principles of the Liberalparty.
Furnished with lips; as, a labial organ pipe.
One of the two or three delicate membranous scales which arenext to the stamens in grasses.

A large sea turtle (Sphargis coriacea), having no bony shell onits back. It is common in the warm and temperate parts of theAtlantic, and sometimes weighs over a thousand pounds; -- called alsoleather turtle, leathery turtle, leather-backed tortoise, etc.
Bad; wicked; false; worthless; slothful. [Obs.] Chaucer.Not lither in business, fervent in spirit. Bp. Woolton.
The written characters used in the common method of writing; --opposed to shorthand.
A nerve, or string, that is imagined to be essential to life.Daniel.
Shining with a light due to any of the various causes whichproduce luminescence.
a thin plate or scale of anything, as a thin scale growing fromthe petals of certain flowers; or one of the thin plates or scales ofwhich certain shells are composed.
An instrument for triturating the stone in the bladder; alithotrite.
A genus of liguliflorous composite plants, including the falldandelion (L. autumnale), and formerly the true dandelion; -- calledalso lion's tooth.
A literalist.
Milkily; in the manner of milk.
Loyalty. [R.] Stow.
A ray or glimmer of light; a gleam. [Obs.] Chaucer.
Same as Lorry, or Lorrie.
Connected with, or formed in, the lymphatic glands.
Shaped like the Greek letter lambda (as, the lambdoid suturebetween the occipital and parietal bones of the skull.

The workroom of a chemist; also, a place devoted to experimentsin any branch of natural science; as, a chemical, physical, orbiological laboratory. Hence, by extension, a place where somethingis prepared, or some operation is performed; as, the liver is thelaboratory of the bile.
The systematic use of antiseptics in the performance ofoperations and the treatment of wounds; -- so called from JosephLister, an English surgeon.
One engaged in logging. See Log, v. i. [U.S.] Lowell.
See Leden. [Obs.] Chaucer.

A genus of huge, carnivorous, dinosaurian reptiles from theCretaceous formation of the United States. They had very large hindlegs and tail, and are supposed to have been bipedal. Some of thespecies were about eighteen feet high.
An argillaceous sandstone, of a red color, and much seamed; --found in India.
See Lam.
Release; remission; ease; relief. [Obs.] "Of penance had alisse." Chaucer.
The act of lauding; praise; high commendation.
An artificer whose occupation is to make or mend locks.
Of or pertaining to a limit. [Obs.]

The act or process of liquidating; the state of beingliquidated. To go into liquidation (Law), to turn over to a trusteeone's assets and accounts, in order that the several amounts of one'sindebtedness be authoritatively ascertained, and that the assets maybe applied toward their discharge.

A small opening; a small depression or cavity; a space, as avacant space between the cells of plants, or one of the spaces leftamong the tissues of the lower animals, which serve in place ofvessels for the circulation of the body fluids, or the cavity or sac,usually of very small size, in a mucous membrane.
In a legitimate manner; lawfully; genuinely.
Lightness; nimbleness [Archaic] Shak.
One who assists in lynching.
Having the form of a sword, but very long and narrow.
A plant of the genus Lycopodium.

Being in such a state that the component parts move amongthemselves, but do not tend to separate from each other as theparticles of gases and vapors do; neither solid nor aëriform; as,liquid mercury, in distinction from mercury solidified or in a stateof vapor.
In a luculent manner; clearly.
A loop or eye formed on the head rope of a bonnet, by which itis attached to the foot of a sail; -- called also latch and lasket.[Usually in pl.]

Silver. Luna cornea (Old Chem.), horn silver, or fused silverchloride, a tough, brown, translucent mass; -- so called from itsresemblance to horn. Luna moth (Zoöl.), a very large and beautifulAmerican moth (Actias luna). Its wings are delicate light green, witha stripe of purple along the front edge of the anterior wings, theother margins being edged with pale yellow. Each wing has a lunatespot surrounded by rings of light yellow, blue, and black. Thecaterpillar commonly feeds on the hickory, sassafras, and maple.
One to whom a legacy is bequeathed.
An ornament much used in Egyptian architecture, generallyasserted to have been suggested by the Egyptian water lily.

The standard adopted by the Emperor Constantine after hisconversion to Christianity. It is described as a pike bearing a silkbanner hanging from a crosspiece, and surmounted by a golden crown.It bore a monogram of the first two letters (CHR) of the name ofChrist in its Greek form. Later, the name was given to variousmodifications of this standard.
Gray. [Obs.] Chaucer.
To imitate the manner of the Laconians, especially in brief,pithy speech, or in frugality and austerity.
Same as Ladybird.
Course of life; means of support; livelihood. [Obs.]
The act of shedding tears; weeping.
Undergoing the process of becoming stone; having the capacityof being converted into stone; having the quality of petrifyingbodies.
See Loo.
The calico bass.
Tending to limit.
See Lanyard.
Like a lob; consisting of lobs. Sir. P. Sidney.
A word letter; a phonogram, that, for the sake of brevity,represents a word; as, |, i. e., t, for it. Cf. Grammalogue.
A division of amphipod Crustacea, in which the abdomen is smallor rudimentary and the legs are often reduced to five pairs. Thewhale louse, or Cyamus, and Caprella are examples.
See Limoniad.
Lint; esp., lint made into a tent for insertion into wounds orulcers.
See Leme. [Obs.] Holland.
One versed in lichenology.
See Fatherlasher.
The principles or plans of legitimists.
The division of mankind which embraces the smooth-haired races.
