A fainting; a swoon. Jer. Taylor.
A dry sirocco in the Madeira Islands.
Of or pertaining to the Levant. J. Spencer.
A nitrogenous organic base from coal tar, and identical withquinoline. Cf. Quinoline.
pl. of Loaf.
Of or pertaining to lentigo; freckly; scurfy; furfuraceous.
Speech or discourse; a phrase; a form or mode of expression. "Stumbling locutions." G. Eliot.I hate these figures in locution, These about phrases forced byceremony. Marston.
To bend; to box; to stoop. [Archaic] Chaucer. Longfellow.He fair the knight saluted, louting low. Spenser.
To place one's self; to take up one's residence; to settle.[Colloq.]
See Logic.
The principles of the low-church party.
A genus of bacteria, characterized by having their filamentsvery long, slender, and indistinctly articulated.
One who gained the prize in the lampadrome.
One who loathes.
A small lamb.
To make liberal; to free from narrow views or prejudices.To open and to liberalize the mind. Burke.
Slow; sluggish; backward.
of Let, to allow. Chaucer.
One in charge of the larder.
Having lungs that adhere to the pleura.
Having lamellar gills; belonging to the Lamellibranchia.-- n.
A small landau.
The act of playing on a lyre or harp. G. Eliot.
The sky; the atmosphere; the firmament. [Obs. or Scot.]

The amount by which a slide valve at its half stroke overlaps aport in the seat, being equal to the distance the valve must movefrom its mid stroke position in order to begin to open the port. Usedalone, lap refers to outside lap. See Outside lap (below).
Same as List, n., 6.
Such as can be lent. Sherwood.
A weak base identical with betaine; -- so called because foundin the boxthorn (Lycium barbarum). See Betaine.
An inflammation and swelling of the soft parts of the roof ofthe mouth immediately behind the fore teeth in the horse; -- calledalso lampers.
A tearing; laceration. "Lancinations of the spirit." Jer.Taylor.
. Bissextile; a year containing 366 days; every fourth yearwhich leaps over a day more than a common year, giving to Februarytwenty-nine days. See Bissextile.
Yellowish; more or less like buff.
See Lamantin.
A trader in law; one who practices law as if it were a trade.Milton.

Of or pertaining to learning; possessing, or characterized by,learning, esp. scholastic learning; erudite; well-informed; as, alearned scholar, writer, or lawyer; a learned book; a learned theory.The learnedlover lost no time. Spenser.Men of much reading are greatly learned, but may be little knowing.Locke.Words of learned length and thundering sound. Goldsmith.The learned, learned men; men of erudition; scholars.-- Learn"ed*ly, adv. Learn"ed*ness, n.Every coxcomb swears as learnedly as they. Swift.
The quality of being laudable; praiseworthiness;commendableness.
A board used on the lap as a substitute for a table, as bytailors.
A tribe of North American Inedians, inhabiting the northernpart of Mexico. They belong to the Tinneh stock, and are closelyrelated to the Apaches.
See Lymphadenitis.
The process of laminating, or the state of being laminated.
Washing, or cleansing by washing.
Such as can be lifted.
A dry sirocco of Spain.
A trumpet call for rousing soldiers; a reveille. [Obs.]Hudibras.
A kind of type, in size between small pica and bourgeois.
Learned. [Obs.] " Lewed man or lered." Chaucer.
A series of strata in the lower Silurian formations of GreatBritain; -- so named from Llandeilo in Southern Wales. See Chart ofGeology.
Unless. [Obs.] B. Jonson.

Of or pertaining to Laputa, an imaginary flying islanddescribed in Gulliver's Travels as the home of chimericalphilosophers. Hence, fanciful; preposterous; absurd in science orphilosophy. "Laputan ideas." G. Eliot.
To study by candlelight or a lamp; to study by night.
The Canada lynx. See Lynx.
Resembling a lentil in size or form; having the form of adouble-convex lens.

A vocabulary, or book containing an alphabetical arrangement ofthe words in a language or of a considerable number of them, with thedefinition of each; a dictionary; especially, a dictionary of theGreek, Hebrew, or Latin language.

The action of a lever; mechanical advantage gained by thelever. Leverage of a couple (Mech.), the perpendicular distancebetween the lines of action of two forces which act in parallel andopposite directions.-- Leverage of a force, the perpendicular distance from the line inwhich a force acts upon a body to a point about which the body may besupposed to turn.
Of or pertaining to the loins and sacrum; as, the lumbosacralnerve, a branch of one of the lumber nerves which passes over thesacrum.
Same as Lathing.
A kind of glossy silk fabric. See Lutestring.
One given to lewdness.
Same as Liverwort.
Containing lignite; resembling, or of the nature of, lignite;as, lignitic clay. Lignitic group. See Laramie group.
A lying in concealment; hiding. [Obs.]
See Legislature, below.
A rehearsal of a lesson.
One versed in lexicology.
Of or pertaining to language; relating to linguistics, or tothe affinities of languages.
An instrument, devised by Professor Helmholtz, for testing thecolor perception of the eye, or for comparing different lights, as totheir constituent color or their relative whiteness.
In a lucid manner.
Sulphuric ether used as an anæsthetic agent. [R.]

A projection beneath the breech end of a gun barrel. In thelump, In a lump, the whole together; in gross.They may buy them in the lump. Addison.-- Lump coal, coal in large lumps; -- the largest size brought fromthe mine.-- Lump sum, a gross sum without a specification of items; as, toaward a lump sum in satisfaction of all claims and damages.
Slow; in slow time; slowly; -- rarely written lente.
One of an extinct family of trees allied to the modern clubmosses, and including Lepidodendron and its allies.
One who loafs; a lazy lounger. Lowell.
A vessel carrying at the masthead a brilliant light, and mooredoff a shoal or place of dangerous navigation as a guide for mariners.
See Lanier.
Belonging, or relating, to Latium, a country of ancient Italy.See Latin.
To take luncheon. Beaconsfield.
A bone of the human body which was supposed by certainRabbinical writers to be indestructible. Its location was a matter ofdispute. Brande & C.
The doctrine or science of the origin of the minerals composingthe globe.
One who gives a license; as, a licenser of the press.
A race run by young men with lighted torches in their hands. Hewho reached the goal first, with his torch unextinguished, gained theprize.

The state or quality of being left-handed; awkwardness.An awkward address, ungraceful attitudes and actions, and a certainleft-handiness (if I may use the expression) proclaim low education.Chesterfield.
To permit or authorize by license; to give license to; as, tolicense a man to preach. Milton. Shak.
Tender regard; mercy; favor. Ps. lxxxix. 33.
Linen goods collectively; linen underwear, esp. of women; theclothing of linen and cotton with its lace, etc., worn by a women.
See Leveful. [Obs.] Chaucer.
Campylotropous.
Bearing flax; producing linen.
A washing or bathing; also, a clyster.
Small steel plates combined together so as to slide one uponthe form a piece of armor.

One of a class of auxiliary numbers, devised by John Napier, ofMerchiston, Scotland (1550-1617), to abridge arithmeticalcalculations, by the use of addition and subtraction in place ofmultiplication and division.
Same as Lacertian.
A narrow strip of land. [Obs.]
A workman whose business it is to shape boots or shoes, orplace leather smoothly, on lasts; a tool for stretching leather on alast.
Resembling lead. Sir T. Elyot.
One who leads a pack horse; a miller's servant. [Obs. or Local]
The internal ear. See Note under Ear.
Having no lid, or not covered with the lids, as the eyes;hence, sleepless; watchful.A lidless watcher of the public weal. Tennyson.
A lexicographer. [R.] Southey.
A genus of composite herbs, several of which are cultivated foesalad; lettuce.
Lively in walking or running; brisk; light-footed.
The quality or state of being liquescent. Johnson.
See Landing waiter, under Landing, a.
Not having a full complement of men; as, a vessel light-handed.
In Gothic vaulting, any rib which does not spring from theimpost and is not a ridge rib, but passes from one boss orintersection of the principal ribs to another.
An Indo-European people, allied to the Lithuanians and OldPrussians, and inhabiting a part of the Baltic provinces of Russia.
One who labors at night and sleeps in the day.
That which is laid; a stratum; a bed; one thickness, course, orfold laid over another; as, a layer of clay or of sand in the earth;a layer of bricks, or of plaster; the layers of an onion.
A trough used by miners to receive the powdered ore from thebox where it is beaten, or for carrying water to the stamps, or otherapparatus, for comminuting, or sorting, the ore.
One who applies himself to laryngology.
An instrument for performing laryngotomy.
A number of hermitages or cells in the same neighborhoodoccupied by anchorites who were under the same superior. C. Kingsley.
A pike when full grown. Halliwell.
The gigantic sugar pine of California and Oregon (PinusLambertiana). It has the leaves in fives, and cones a foot long. Thetimber is soft, and like that of the white pine of the EasternStates.
The Sweet William (Dianthus barbatus).

A small decorative fold or flap, esp, of lace or muslin, in agarment or headdress. Swift. Lappet moth (Zoöl.), one of severalspecies of bombycid moths, which have stout, hairy caterpillars, flatbeneath. Two common American species (Gastropacha Americana, andTolype velleda) feed upon the apple tree.
A leguminous plant of the genus Ervum (Ervum Lens), of smallsize, common in the fields in Europe. Also, its seed, which is usedfor food on the continent.
Belonging, or relating, to the Lycopodiaceæ, an order ofcryptogamous plants (called also club mosses) with branching stems,and small, crowded, one-nerved, and usually pointed leaves.

A genus of ranunculaceous plants (Delphinium), having showyflowers, and a spurred calyx. They are natives of the North Temperatezone. The commonest larkspur of the gardens is D. Consolida. Theflower of the bee larkspur (D. elatum) has two petals bearded withyellow hairs, and looks not unlike a bee.
The science of languages, or of the origin, signification, andapplication of words; glossology.
A larder. [Obs.]
One who describes lichens; one versed in lichenography.
To make lame.If you happen to let child fall and lame it. Swift.
The art or practice of measuring distances or lengths. Cheyne.
A lyric composition. Gray.
One who, or that which, loosens.
To beat severely. [Low] Nares.
Resembling an earthworm; vermiform.

A rope or long thong of leather with, a running noose, used forcatching horses, cattle, etc. Lasso cell (Zoöl.), one of a peculiarkind of defensive and offensive stinging cells, found in greatnumbers in all coelenterates, and in a few animals of other groups.They are most highly developed in the tentacles of jellyfishes,hydroids, and Actiniæ. Each of these cells is filled with, fluid, andcontains a long, slender, often barbed, hollow thread coiled upwithin it. When the cell contracts the thread is quickly ejected,being at the same time turned inside out. The thread is able topenetrate the flesh of various small, soft-bodied animals, andcarries a subtle poison by which they are speedily paralyzed andkilled. The threads, at the same time, hold the prey in position,attached to the tentacles. Some of the jellyfishes, as the Portugueseman-of-war, and Cyanea, are able to penetrate the human skin, andinflict painful stings in the same way. Called also nettling cell,cnida, cnidocell.
Not having a leg.
A genus of annelids, belonging to the Oligochæta, and includingthe common earthworms. See Earthworm.
Giving life or spirit; having power to give life; inspiriting;invigorating.
To spread over with lather; as, to lather the face.
One who, or that which, lodges; one who occupies a hired roomin another's house.
Legateship. [Obs.]
Such as can be leased.
An instrument for ascertaining the specific gravity of liquids.
Having the form of a lance.
That part of the reserve force in Germany which is called outlast.
The quality or habit of being lenient; lenity. [Obs.] Blount.
The habit or practice of talking continually or excessively;inclination to talk too much; talkativeness; garrulity.Too great loquacity and too great taciturnity by fits. Arbuthnot.
A feast at the time of shearing lambs.
Goggles intended to rectify strabismus by permitting visiononly directly in front. Knight.

The representation of a piece of latticework used as a bearing,the bands being vertical and horizontal. Lattice bridge, a bridgesupported by lattice girders, or latticework trusses.-- Lattice girder (Arch.), a girder of which the wed consists ofdiagonal pieces crossing each other in the manner of latticework.-- Lattice plant (Bot.), an aquatic plant of Madagascar (Ouvirandrafenestralis), whose leaves have interstices between their ribs andcross veins, so as to resemble latticework. A second species is O.Berneriana. The genus is merged in Aponogeton by recent authors.
The lugworm.
The soft woolly hair which covers most parts of the mammalfetus, and in man is shed before or soon after birth.
The latter, or second, mowing; the aftermath.
Having indistinct spots, paler at their margins.
Same as Lawe, v. t. [Obs.]
Fit to be levied; capable of being assessed and collected; as,sums leviable by course of law. Bacon.
A light open cotton fabric used for window curtains.
The diet or legislative body; as, the Landtag of Prussia.
A leash. [Obs.]
Same as Photolithography.
Loathsomeness. [Obs.]
Flowing copiously. [Obs.]

Made of wood; consisting of wood; of the nature of, orresembling, wood; woody.It should be tried with shoots of vines and roots of red roses; forit may be they, being of a moreligneous nature, will incorporate withthe tree itself. Bacon.Ligneous marble, wood coated or prepared so as to resemble marble.
A lay; a German song. It differs from the French chanson, andthe Italian canzone, all three being national.The German Lied is perhaps the most faithful reflection of thenational sentiment. Grove.

An officer who bore an ax and fasces or rods, as ensigns of hisoffice. His duty was to attend the chief magistrates when theyappeared in public, to clear the way, and cause due respect to bepaid to them, also to apprehend and punish criminals.Lictors and rods, the ensigns of their power. Milton.
From a lithological point of view; as, to consider a stratumlithologically.
Lanceolate.
Lately; of late; recently; at a later, as distinguished from aformer, period.Latterly Milton was short and thick. Richardson.
A bitter principle found in the bark of the privet (Ligustrumvulgare), and extracted as a white crystalline substance with a warm,bitter taste; -- called also ligustron.
Lent. [Obs.] Piers Plowman.
The stalk or petiole which supports a leaf.
A cutting off, as of branches; that which is cut off; leavings.The loppings made from that stock whilst it stood. Burke.

The author or compiler of a lexicon or dictionary.Every other author may aspire to praise; the lexicographer can onlyhope to escape reproach; and even this negative recompense has beenyet granted to very few. Johnson.
The science of loxodromics. [R.]
Slackening; retarding. Same as Rallentando.
Light-ship.
To stone. [Obs.]
Applied to boiled potatoes cut into small pieces and heated inoil or butter. They are usually flavored with onion and parsley.

Pertaining to sailing on rhumb lines; as, loxodromic tables.Loxodromic curve or line (Geom.), a line on the surface of a sphere,which always makes an equal angle with every meridian; the rhumbline. It is the line on which a ship sails when her course is alwaysin the direction of one and the same point of the compass.
A person employed on, or who manages, a lighter.
In a languishing manner.
By the use of logarithms.
Same as Lory.
A linget or ingot; also, a mold for casting metals. See Linget.
The disposition or endeavor to level all distinctions of rankin society.
Shaped like the tongue or a strap; ligulate.
A dull, sluggish person; a lubber; a lob. [Low]
Having no desire or inclination; indifferent; heedless;spiritless. " A listless unconcern." Thomson.Benumbed with cold, and listless of their gain. Dryden.I was listless, and desponding. Swift.
Having a brown color tonged with red, as of flame seen throughsmoke.
A lazy person. [Colloq.]

from Laugh, v. i. Laughing falcon (Zoöl.), a South Americanhawk (Herpetotheres cachinnans); -- so called from its notes, whichresemble a shrill laughing.-- Laughing gas (Chem.), hyponitrous oxide, or protoxide ofnitrogen; -- so called from the exhilaration and laughing which itsometimes produces when inhaled. It is much used as an anæstheticagent.-- Laughing goose (Zoöl.), the European white-fronted goose.-- Laughing gull. (Zoöl.) (a) A common European gull (Xemaridibundus); -- called also pewit, black cap, red-legged gull, andsea crow. (b) An American gull (Larus atricilla). In summer the headis nearly black, the back slate color, and the five outer primariesblack.-- Laughing hyena (Zoöl.), the spotted hyena. See Hyena.-- Laughing jackass (Zoöl.), the great brown kingfisher (Dacelogigas), of Australia; -- called also giant kingfisher, and gogobera.-- Laughing owl (Zoöl.), a peculiar owl (Sceloglaux albifacies) ofNew Zealand, said to be on the verge of extinction. The name alludesto its notes.
An order of wormlike, degraded, parasitic arachnids. They havetwo pairs of retractile hooks, near the mouth. Called alsoPentastomida.
The act of luxating, or the state of being luxated; adislocation.
See Leach.
Having a lamellate bill, as ducks and geese.
Full of love. [Obs.] Sylvester.
, Having no lips.
Having a form like that of the new moon; shaped like acrescent.
Connected; tied; -- a term used when successive tones are to beproduced in a closely connected, smoothly gliding manner. It is oftenindicated by a tie, thus staccato.
A pigment formed by combining some coloring matter, usually byprecipitation, with a metallic oxide or earth, esp. with aluminiumhydrate; as, madder lake; Florentine lake; yellow lake, etc.
A fathom. [Obs.] Domesday Book.
The act or process of representing by letters.
See Luny.
The posterior, inner process of the stipes on the maxillæ ofinsects.
Of or pertaining to the Læmodipoda.
The state or quality of being lax; want of tenseness,strictness, or exactness.
Deadly; bringing death or destruction.
The science of the derivation and signification of words; thatbranch of learning which treats of the signification and applicationof words.
A fossil leaf or impression of a leaf.
A salt of lactic acid.
See Lixivial.
A small room from which the magazine of a naval vessel islighted, being separated from the magazine by heavy glass windows.
A mineral of a light indigo-blue color, occurring in smallmasses, or in monoclinic crystals; blue spar. It is a hydrousphosphate of alumina and magnesia.
One who follows the business of laundering.
Having thick lips.
Abatement; also, cessation; as, it blew a gale for three dayswithout any let-up. [Colloq.]
,. v. i. To ply the whip; to strike; to uttercensure orsarcastic language.To laugh at follies, or to lash at vice. Dryden.To lash out, to strike out wildly or furiously.

A genus of small pectinibranch mollusks, having thick spiralshells, abundant between tides on nearly all rocky seacoasts. Theyfeed on seaweeds. The common periwinkle is a well-known example. SeePeriwinkle.
See Louver. [Obs.] Bp. Hall.
An object of ridicule; a butt of sport. Shak.When he talked, he talked nonsense, and made himself thelaughingstock of his hearers. Macaulay.
Of or pertaining to the shrikes (family Laniidæ).
A dormer window.

A genus of Old World plants belonging to the Pink family(Caryophyllaceæ). Most of the species have brilliantly coloredflowers and cottony leaves, which may have anciently answered aswicks for lamps. The botanical name is in common use for the gardenspecies. The corn cockle (Lychnis Githago) is a common weed in wheatfields.
See 3d Leech.
Covered with, or having many, lilies.By sandy Ladon's lilied banks. Milton.
Barking. [Obs.] Tickell.
To make the subject of a lawsuit; to contest in law; toprosecute or defend by pleadings, exhibition of evidence, andjudicial debate in a court; as, to litigate a cause.
A daddy longlegs.
Made of linen; as, linen cloth; a linen stocking.
A ledge; a right-angled projection.
The state or quality of being legitimate; lawfulness;genuineness.
One of the higher alcohols of the paraffine series obtainedfrom spermaceti as a white crystalline solid. It is so called becauseit occurs in the ethereal salt of lauric acid.
Lycanthropic.
Yielding or producing wood.

A tumor having a structure resembling that of a lymphaticgland; -- called also lymphadenoma. Malignant lymphoma, a fataldisease characterized by the formation in various parts of the bodyof new growths resembling lymphatic glands in structure.
The act of stoning. [Obs.] Bp. Hall.
One who languishes.
See Lecturn.
Slipping; sliding; gliding. [R.]
In a lyrical manner.
An organ for aërial respiration; -- commonly in the plural.My lungs began to crow like chanticleer. Shak.
The deposit of slime at the mouth of a river; slime.
The business of cutting or getting timber or logs from theforest for lumber. [U.S.]
One who lets or permits; one who lets anything for hire.
Less; smaller; inferior.God made . . . the lesser light to rule the night. Gen. i. 15.
Place; room; stead; -- used only in the phrase in lieu of, thatis, instead of.The plan of extortion had been adopted in lieu of the scheme ofconfiscation. Burke.
A libeler.
One of the Lepidoptera.

A tree (Guaiacum officinale) found in the warm latitudes ofAmerica, from which the guaiacum of medicine is procured. Its wood isvery hard and heavy, and is used for various mechanical purposes, asfor the wheels of ships' blocks, cogs, bearings, and the like. SeeGuaiacum.
Producing milk or a milklike juice or fluid, as the milkweed.See Latex.
An agent, as mercury, iodine, etc., which promotes theliquefying processes of the system, and increases the secretions.
A slender marine fish of the genus Ammodytes, especiallyAmmodytes tobianus of the English coast; -- called also sand lance.
A lord; a landholder, esp. one who holds land directly of thecrown. [Scot.]
A salt of lithic or uric acid; a urate. [Obs.] [Written alsolithiate.]
Having latitude, or wide extent.
To make literal; to interpret or put in practice according tothe strict meaning of the words; -- opposed to spiritualize; as, toliteralize Scripture.
A small vessel having two or three masts, and a runningbowsprit, and carrying lugsails. See Illustration in Appendix.Totten.
Liability to lapse, err, or apostatize. [Archaic] Coleridge.
A young girl; a lass. [Scot.]

A varnish, consisting of a solution of shell-lac in alcohol,often colored with gamboge, saffron, or the like; -- used forvarnishing metals, papier-maché, and wood. The name is also given tovarnishes made of other ingredients, esp. the tough, solid varnish ofthe Japanese, with which ornamental objects are made.
A tapster. [Obs.]
Working in wool.
Tending to swoon; fainting. [Written also leipothymic.]

To retard; to hinder; to impede; to oppose. [Archaic]He was so strong that no man might him let. Chaucer.He who now letteth will let, until he be taken out of the way. 2.Thess. ii. 7.Mine ancient wound is hardly whole, And lets me from the saddle.Tennyson.
To prate; to gossip; to babble; to blab. [Obs.] Chaucer.
The art of printing colored pictures on canvas from oilpaintings on stone.
Like. [Obs.] Chaucer. Spenser.
A holder, owner, or proprietor of land.-- Land"hold`ing, n. & a.
A lacuna. [R.] Landor.
See Leucoplast.
To listen or listen to; to hearken to. [Obs.] P. Plowman.
Stone-producing; -- said of polyps which form coral.
A genus of evergreen shrubs from the Cape of Good Hope, havinghandsome foliage. Leucadendron argenteum is the silverboom of thecolonists.
An old game at cards. See Loo (a) Tatler.
A mineral of a color between white and steel-gray, with ametallic luster, and consisting chiefly of arsenic and iron.

The capital city of England. London paste (Med.), a paste madeof caustic soda and unslacked lime; -- used as a caustic to destroytumors and other morbid enlargements.-- London pride. (Bot.) (a) A garden name for Saxifraga umbrosa, ahardy perennial herbaceous plant, a native of high lands in GreatBritain. (b) A name anciently given to the Sweet William. Dr. Prior.-- London rocket (Bot.), a cruciferous plant (Sisymbrium Irio) whichsprung up in London abundantly on the ruins of the great fire of1667.
Crowned with laurel, or with a laurel wreath; laureate.[Written also laurelled.]
Of, pertaining to, or derived from, Latin; in the Latin styleor idiom. "Latinistic words." Fitzed. Hall.
Having the nose narrow; -- said esp. of the skull. Opposed toplatyrhine.
A salt of linoleic acid.
Divided into lozenge-shaped compartments, as the field or abearing, by lines drawn in the direction of the bend sinister.
To retire into a den, or hole, and lie dormant in winter; toretreat and lie hid. [R.] G. Shaw.
A legatee. [R.] Ayliffe.
Of or pertaining to Lamaism.
Making sport; tending to excite derision. [Obs.]
One of the Læmodipoda.
Animated; sprightly. [Poetic] Coleridge.-- Life"some*ness, n.
To throw, as a lance; to let fly; to launch.See Whose arm can lanch the surer bolt. Dryden & Lee.
A small dog fondled in the lap.
Composed of dactyls and trochees so arranged as to produce amovement like that of ordinary speech.
Like a lirella. [Written also lirellæform.]
Water impregnated with lime; esp., an artificial solution oflime for medicinal purposes.
Of or pertaining to Leon, in Spain.-- n. sing. & pl.
In a secret or concealed manner; invisibly.
The formation of stony concretions or calculi in any part ofthe body, especially in the bladder and urinary passages. Dunglison.
A suborder of primates, including the lemurs, the aye-aye, andallied species. [Written also Lemuroida.]
A kind of litter or portable couch.
. A peculiar sort of stitch formed by the locking of twothreads together, as in the work done by some sewing machines. SeeStitch.
A lamp or candlestick. [R.]By him who 'mid the golden lampads went. Trench.
A French lyceum, or secondary school supported by the Frenchgovernment, for preparing students for the university.

One of a order of nuns founded in 1812 at Loretto, in Kentucky.The members of the order (called also Sisters of Loretto, or Friendsof Mary at the Foot of the Cross) devote themselves to the cause ofeducation and the care of destitute orphans, their labors beingchiefly confined to the Western United States.
The act or operation of levigating.
A white opacity in the cornea of the eye; -- called alsoalbugo.
To move heavily; to lounge or idle; to loll. [Law.] CharlesReade.
One of a series of anhydrides resembling the lactams, but of animido type; as, isatine is a lactim. Cf. Lactam.
Of, pertaining to, or produced by, lithotypy.
A lapidary. Ray.
See Llama.
In a laconic manner.
Having a smooth surface, as if polished.
A rich, sweet, red Neapolitan wine.
Gainful; profitable. [Obs.] Boyle.
A reader of lections; formerly, a person designated to readlessons to the illiterate.
A hump-backed person; -- so called sportively. [Eng.]Richardson (Dict.).
An expression of languor.
A large antelope of North Africa (Oryx leucoryx), allied to thegemsbok.
The river lamprey (Ammocoetes, or Lampetra, fluviatilis).
A tie or brace; a syncopation.
The farthest point of the moon's northing and southing, in itsmonthly revolution. [Obs.]
See Labidometer.
The office of a legate.
Having one's thoughts directed toward mean or insignificantsubjects.
The quality of being logical.
See Ladanum.
A man who follows the business of laundering.
One who studies the Lepidoptera.

One of a family (Lernæidæ) of parasitic Crustacea foundattached to fishes and other marine animals. Some species penetratethe skin and flesh with the elongated head, and feed on the viscera.See Illust. in Appendix.
State, or office, of a laureate.
A cavity or hollow.[Obs.] Sir M. Hale.
Of or pertaining to lumbago.
The lungs of an animal or bird; -- sometimes coarsely appliedto the lungs of a human being.

Act of localizing, or state of being localized. Cerebrallocalization (Physiol.), the localization of the control of specialfunctions, as of sight or of the various movements of the body, inspecial regions of the brain.
A native or inhabitant of Lucca, in Tuscany; in the plural, thepeople of Lucca.
Of or pertaining to Lapland.
A coarse American composite weed (Polymnia Uvedalia).
Prolonged, or relatively more prolonged, in utterance; -- saidof vowels and syllables. See Short, a., 13, and Guide toPronunciation, §§ 22, 30.
Lore; learning. [Obs.]
Pertaining to, or designating, a nitrogenous organic substanceof the uric acid group, called leucoturic acid or oxalantin. SeeOxalantin.
See Lamprey.
The act of lampooning; a lampoon, or lampoons.
A little or insignificant lord. Goldsmith.
To descend; to light.O Lord, let thy mercy lighten upon us. Book of Common Prayer [Eng.Ed.]
After the manner of the Levites; in accordance with thelevitical law.
A vagabond; a vagrant. [Written also landleaper and landloper.]"Bands of landloupers." Moltey.
One who disobeys the law; a criminal.-- Law"break`ing, n. & a.
Luxuriance. [Obs.]
Having a leaflike membrane on the nose; -- said of certainbats, esp. of the genera Phyllostoma and Rhinonycteris. See Vampire.
To illumine. [Obs.] Spenser.
See Lymphoma.
To make a lady of; to make ladylike. [Obs.] Massinger.
The marking out of the boundaries, or identifying the place orsite of, a piece of land, according to the description given in anentry, plan, map, etc. Burrill. Bouvier.

A transparent limpid liquid, slightly blue in color, consistingof a mixture of liquefied oxygen and nitrogen. It is prepared bysubjecting air to great pressure and then cooling it by its ownexpansion to a temperature below the boiling point of itsconstituents  (N -194º C; O -183º C.).
With longing. Dryden.
A layman. Bp. Morton.
One of the half-breed descendants of whites and Indians; amestizo; -- so called throughout Central America. They are usually ofa yellowish orange tinge. Am. Cyc.
Look; see; behold; observe. " Lo, here is Christ." Matt. xxiv.23. " Lo, we turn to the Gentiles." Acts xiii. 46.
One who practices sleight of hand; a prestidigitator.
See Letterwood.
Of or pertaining to stone; inscribed on stone; as, a lapidarianrecord.
Having large, pendent ears. [Obs.] Bp. Hall.
The closing of a factory or workshop by an employer, usually inorder to bring the workmen to satisfactory terms by a suspension ofwages.
Having the form or structure of a larva.
To inflict punishment upon, especially death, without the formsof law, as when a mob captures and hangs a suspected person. SeeLynch law.

Having no leaves or foliage; bearing no foliage. "Leaflessgroves." Cowper.-- Leaf"less*ness, n. Leafless plants, plants having no foliage,though leaves may be present in the form of scales and bracts. SeeLeaf, n., 1 and 2.

The work done by a steam engine or other prime mover whenworking. Load line, or Load water line (Naut.), the line on theoutside of a vessel indicating the depth to which it sinks in thewater when loaded.
To listen. [Obs.] Chaucer. Spenser.
See Litchi.
A medicine having, or supposed to have, the power of expellingcalculous matter with the urine. Hooper.
Lacteal; conveying chyle.
Composed of, or having, lamellæ; lamelliform.
Tincture of opium, used for various medical purposes.
The act of filing or polishing.
The state or quality of being latent.To simplify the discussion, I shall distinguish three degrees of thislatency. Sir W. Hamilton.
Having edges or ends united by a lap weld; as, a lap-weldedpipe.
Having the form of a lens; lens-shaped.
A body of legions; legions, collectively. [R.] Pollok.
The quality of being limited.

A malicious publication expressed either in print or inwriting, or by pictures, effigies, or other signs, tending to exposeanother to public hatred, contempt, or ridicule. Such publication isindictable at common law.
The fruit of the Japanese medlar (Photinia Japonica). It is aslarge as a small plum, but grows in clusters, and contains four orfive large seeds. Also, the tree itself.
The condition of being a layman. [Obs.] Milton.
A stalked barnacle of the genus Lepas, or family Lepadidæ; agoose barnacle. Also used adjectively.
The European cricket warbler.
See Livelihood. [Obs.]
To lick. [Obs.]
A cutaneous disease occurring under two distinct forms.
Destitute of luster; dim; dull.
The owning of land.-- a.
Long-windedness.American longiloquence in oratory. Fitzed. Hall.

A city of France celebrated for certain manufactures. Lisleglove, a fine summer glove, made of Lisle thread.-- Lisle lace, a fine handmade lace, made at Lisle.-- Lisle thread, a hard twisted cotton thread, originally producedat Lisle.

Descent in a line from a common progenitor; progeny; race;descending line of offspring or ascending line of parentage.Both the lineage and the certain sire From which I sprung, from meare hidden yet. Spenser.
Taken by licking with the tongue. "Sirups and lambativemedicines." Sir T. Browne.
An inhabitant of the moon.

That part of the stage upon which the limelight as cast,usually where the most important action is progressing or where theleading player or players are placed and upon which the attention ofthe spectators is therefore concentrated. Hence, consspicuousposition before the public; as, politicians who are never happyexcept in the limelight.
See Lampas.

That which happens to a person; an event, good or ill,affecting one's interests or happiness, and which is deemed casual; acourse or series of such events regarded as occurring by chance;chance; hap; fate; fortune; often, one's habitual or characteristicfortune; as, good, bad, ill, or hard luck. Luck is often used forgood luck; as, luck is better than skill.If thou dost play with him at any game, Thou art sure to lose; and ofthat natural luck, He beats thee 'gainst the odds. Shak.Luck penny, a small sum given back for luck to one who pays money.[Prov. Eng.] -- To be is luck, to receive some good, or to meet withsome success, in an unexpected manner, or as the result ofcircumstances beyond one's control; to be fortunate.
A beverage consisting of lemon juice mixed with water andsweetened.
Pertaining to, or designating, an acid of the formic acidseries, found in the tar, wax, or paraffine obtained by distillingcertain kinds of wood, as the beech.
Having limbs; -- much used in composition; as, large-limbed;short-limbed.Innumerous living creatures, perfect forms, Limbed and full grown.Milton.
A sweetheart, of either sex; a gallant, or a mistress; --usually in a bad sense. [Archaic] Chaucer. Spenser. Shak.
A kind of loaded die. [Obs.]
A genus of marine fishes, including the wrasses of Europe. SeeWrasse.
Depositing living larvæ, instead of eggs; -- said of certaininsects.
In a linguistic manner; from the point of view of a linguist.Tylor.
In a lagging manner; loiteringly.
Resembling leather in appearance or consistence; tough. "Aleathery skin." Grew.

Given to flattery or deceit; flattering; cozening. [Obs.]Amongst the many simoniacal that swarmed in the land, Herbert, Bishopof Thetford, must not be forgotten; nick-named Losing, that is, theFratterer. Fuller.
A verse, or the words which form a certain number of feet,according to the measure.In the preceding line Ulysses speaks of Nausicaa. Broome.
See Ledgment
The blade of a leaf; the broad, expanded portion of a petal orsepal of a flower. Gray.
A kind of halter usually made of raw hide.
Resembling lymph; also, resembling a lymphatic gland; adenoid;as, lymphoid tissue.
A robber; a pirate; hence, loosely, a rogue or rascal.
The act of liberating or the state of being liberated.This mode of analysis requires perfect liberation from all prejudgedsystem. Pownall.
Using, or interlarded with, pretentious words; bombastic; as, alexiphanic writer or speaker; lexiphanic writing.
Like, or becoming, a lawyer; as, lawyerlike sagacity. "Lawyerlymooting of this point." Milton.
A stringed instrument of music; a kind of harp much used by theancients, as an accompaniment to poetry.
Leprosy. [Obs.] Holland.
An iron-potash mica, of a raven-black color, usually found ingranitic rocks in small six-sided tables, or as an aggregation ofminute opaque scales. See Mica.
A musician who plays on the harp or lyre; a composer of lyricalpoetry. Shelley.
Having relation to changes in currents that depend on themoon's phases. Bache.
An albuminous substance resembling casein, found as acharacteristic ingredient of the seeds of leguminous and grain-bearing plants.

Governed by the rules of law as distinguished from the rules ofequity; as, legal estate; legal assets. Bouvier. Burrill. Legal cap.See under Cap.-- Legal tender. (a) The act of tendering in the performance of acontract or satisfaction of a claim that which the law prescribes orpermits, and at such time and place as the law prescribes or permits.(b) That currency, or money, which the law authorizes a debtor totender and requires a creditor to receive. It differs in differentcountries.
pl. of Leaf.
The state of being a landlord; the characteristics of alandlord; specifically, in Great Britain, the relation of landlordsto tenants, especially as regards leased agricultural lands. J. S.Mill.
One who curs or engraves precious stones.
See Louk. [Obs.] Chaucer.
Having a broad breastbone, or sternum; -- said of anthropoidapes.

A shrub of the genus Syringa. There are six species, natives ofEurope and Asia. Syringa vulgaris, the common lilac, and S. Persica,the Persian lilac, are frequently cultivated for the fragrance andbeauty of their purplish or white flowers. In the British coloniesvarious other shrubs have this name.
A modified form of Buddhism which prevails in Thibet, Mongolia,and some adjacent parts of Asia; -- so called from the name of itspriests. See 2d Lama.
Containing, or resembling, lard; of the character orconsistency of lard.
A hard, or stony, plantlike organism, as the gorgonians,corals, and corallines, esp. those gorgonians having a calcareousaxis. All the lithophytes except the corallines are animals.

Adapted to excite laughter, without scorn or contempt;sportive. Broome.A chapter upon German rhetoric would be in the same ludicrouspredicament as Van Troil's chapter on the snakes of Iceland, whichdelivers its business in one summary sentence, announcing, thatsnakes in Iceland -- there are none. De Quincey.
The termination of a right or privilege through neglect toexercise it within the limited time, or through failure of somecontingency; hence, the devolution of a right or privilege.
Having a like disposition or purpose; of the same mind.Tillotson.
Lamarckism.

A resinous substance produced mainly on the banyan tree, but tosome extent on other trees, by the Coccus lacca, a scale-shapedinsect, the female of which fixes herself on the bark, and exudesfrom the margin of her body this resinous substance.
Lost.Neither of them she found where she them lore. Spenser.
Bearing injuries or provocation for a long time; patient; noteasily provoked.The Lord God, merciful and gracious, long-suffering, and abundant ingoodness and truth. Ex. xxxiv. 6.
Crafty; cunning; mischievous; wicked; treacherous;lazy.[Archaic]He [the dwarf] was waspish, arch, and litherly. Sir W. Scott.
To learn. See Lere, to learn. [Obs.]
A lithotriptist.
One who lounges; ar idler.
To modify by contraction of the lip opening.
The act of liberalizing.
Of or pertaining to logography.
A bitter principle extracted from hops.
Of or pertaining to a natural order of plants of which thegenus Lobelia is the type.
The condition or quality or being lanky.
Piecemeal. [Obs.] "To tear her limbmeal." Shak.

One of several species of East Indian and Asiatic fresh-waterfishes of the genus Ophiocephalus, remarkable for their power ofliving out of water, and for their tenacity of life; -- called alsowalking fishes.
Length.
Having (such) a liver; used in composition; as, white-livered.
Having the form of liber, or resembling liber. Libriform cells,peculiar wood cells which are very slender and relatively thick-walled, and occasionally are furnished with bordered pits. Goodale.
To plunder; to carry off as plunder or a prize lawfullyobtained by war.Looting parties . . . ransacking the houses. L.O

A game of chance, played with cards, on which are inscribednumbers, and any contrivance (as a wheel containing numbered balls)for determining a set of numbers by chance. The player holding a cardhaving on it the set of numbers drawn from the wheel takes the stakesafter a certain percentage of them has been deducted for the dealer.A variety of lotto is called keno. [Often written loto.]
Effort to overcome in contest; struggle; endeavor. [R.]Farindon.
Slowness; sluggishness. [Obs.]
Same as Lyrid.
Having lantern jaws or long, thin jaws; as, a lantern-jawedperson.

Pertaining to, or characteristic of, the lion; as, a leoninelook; leonine repacity.-- Le"o*nine*ly, adv. Leonine verse, a kind of verse, in which theend of the line rhymes with the middle; -- so named from Leo, orLeoninus, a Benedictine and canon of Paris in the twelfth century,who wrote largely in this measure, though he was not the inventor.The following line is an example:Gloria factorum temere conceditur horum.
Lacerating, or having the power to lacerate; as, lacerativehumors. Harvey.
A lake; a bay or arm of the sea. [Scot.]

A genus of gigantic trees, chiefly Brazilian, of the orderMyrtaceæ, having woody capsules opening by an apical lid. LecythisZabucajo yields the delicious sapucaia nuts. L. Ollaria produces themonkey-pots, its capsules. Its bark separates into thin sheets, likepaper, used by the natives for cigarette wrappers.

A brace and a half; a tierce; three; three creatures of anykind, especially greyhounds, foxes, bucks, and hares; hence, thenumber three in general.[I] kept my chamber a leash of days. B. Jonson.Then were I wealthier than a leash of kings. Tennyson.
Same as Labiate, a. (a).
The state or quality of being alive; possession of energy orvigor; animation; quickening.
Consisting of stones.
See Limaille. [Obs.] Chaucer.
A vessel to carry liquid metal from the furnace to the mold.
Somewhat lop; inclined to lop.
Armed with light weapons or accouterments.
One who lacquers, especially one who makes a business oflacquering.
Same as Lac, one hundred thousand.
A basketful. [Obs.]
Capable of being limited.
The person to whom a lease is given, or who takes an estate bylease. Blackstone.
Laudatory.
Pertaining to lycanthropy.
A lane. See Loanin. [Prov. Eng.]
Of or pertaining to the Lapps; Laplandish.-- n.
A native or inhabitant of Lapland; -- called also Lapp.
In a limping manner.
A lymphatic gland.

Of or pertaining to Lydia, a country of Asia Minor, or to itsinhabitants; hence, soft; effeminate; -- said especially of one ofthe ancient Greek modes or keys, the music in which was of a soft,pathetic, or voluptuous character.Softly sweet in Lydian measures, Soon he soothed his soul topleasures. Dryden.Lydian stone, a flint slate used by the ancients to try gold andsilver; a touchstone. See Basanite.
Like or belonging to the Lacertilia.
the daffodil; -- so named from its blossoming in spring.
Like a living being; resembling life; giving an accuraterepresentation; as, a lifelike portrait.-- Life"like`ness, n. Poe.

A rock consisting chiefly of calcium carbonate or carbonate oflime. It sometimes contains also magnesium carbonate, and is thencalled magnesian or dolomitic limestone. Crystalline limestone iscalled marble.
pl. of Life.
Same Ledge.[Obs.] Spenser.
Covered with clay; miry.
Pertaining to seaweeds of the genus Laminaria, or to that zoneof the sea (from two to ten fathoms in depth) where the seaweeds ofthis genus grow.
The state of being a lion.
Like a lecher; addicted to lewdness; lustful; also, lust-provoking. "A lecherous thing is wine." Chaucer.-- Lech"er*ous*ly, adv.-- Lech"er*ous*ness, n.
One subject to the jurisdiction of a court-leet.
Illuminated. [Obs.] Wyclif.
Of or pertaining to Luther; adhering to the doctrines of Lutheror the Lutheran Church.
The quality of being lucent.
A bundle or fascicle of muscular fibers.
One who, or that which, leaps.
Dull; stupid. Shak.A rabble of loggerheaded physicians. Urquhart.
The state or quality of being lousy.
The act of legislating; preparation and enactment of laws; thelaws enacted.Pythagoras joined legislation to his philosophy. Lyttelton.
The science which treats of lichens.
A tearing in pieces. [R.]
Bred, or like one bred, in a low condition of life;characteristic or indicative of such breeding; rude; impolite;vulgar; as, a lowbred fellow; a lowbred remark.
Full of lumps, or small compact masses.
A substance isomeric with starch, extracted from severalspecies of moss and lichen, esp. from Iceland moss.
The office of a legislator. Halifax.
A general name for all those placental mammals that have abrain with few or no cerebral convolutions, as Rodentia, Insectivora,etc.
One who holds low-church principles.
The powdered leaves of the baobab tree, used by the Africans tomix in their soup, as the southern negroes use powdered sassafras.Cf. Couscous.
A writ of execution at common law.
Having the tarsus covered behind with a horny sheath continuouson both sides, as in most singing birds, except the larks.

A large, savage, carnivorous mammal (Felis leopardus). It is ofa yellow or fawn color, with rings or roselike clusters of blackspots along the back and sides. It is found in Southern Asia andAfrica. By some the panther (Felis pardus) is regarded as a varietyof leopard. Hunting leopard. See Cheetah. Leopard cat (Zoöl.) any oneof several species or varieties of small, spotted cats found inAfrica, Southern Asia, and the East Indies; esp., Felis Bengalensis.-- Leopard marmot. See Gopher, 2.
The central keel-bearing part of the sternum in birds.
To legitimate.
Of or pertaining to, or of the nature of, a lientery.-- n. (Med.)
Having a form somewhat like leptus; -- said of active insectlarvæ having three pairs of legs. See Larva.
A group of Mammalia, including the marsupials and monotremes; -- so called because the corpus callosum is rudimentary.
A Linnæan genus of parasitic Entomostraca, -- the same as thefamily Lernæidæ.
A cutting through the walls of the abdomen, as in the Cæsareansection.
To lend; to grant; to permit. [Obs.] Chaucer.
Liable to lapse.
A mineral of a greenish yellow color; it is a silicate ofglucina, lime, and soda with fluorine. Called also leucophanite.
Of or pertaining praise, or to the expression of praise; as,laudatory verses; the laudatory powers of Dryden. Sir J. Stephen.

An eel-shaped ganoid fish of the order Dipnoi, having bothgills and lungs. It inhabits the rivers of South America. The name isalso applied to a related African species (Protopterus annectens).The lepidosirens grow to a length of from four to six feet. Calledalso doko.
Learned or literary men. See Literatus.Shakespearean commentators, and other literati. Craik.
To weep. [R.] Blount.
An albuminous mineral of a rich blue color. Same as Lazuli,which see.
Having leaflike expansions on the legs; -- said of certaininsects; as, the leaf-footed bug (Leptoglossus phyllopus).

Any one of several small, fresh-water, cyprinoid fishes of thegenera Cobitis, Nemachilus, and allied genera, having six or morebarbules around the mouth. They are found in Europe and Asia. Thecommon European species (N. barbatulus) is used as a food fish.
Producing light; yielding light; transmitting light; as, theluminiferous ether.
Lixiviating; the process of separating a soluble substance formone that is insoluble, by washing with some solvent, as water;leaching.
Caused by Lethe. " Letheed dullness." [Obs.] Shak.

A member of the Roman Catholic Church. (Dog Latin, barbarousLatin; a jargon in imitation of Latin; as, the log Latin ofschoolboys.-- Late Latin, Low Latin, terms used indifferently to designate thelatest stages of the Latin language; low Latin (and, perhaps, lateLatin also), including the barbarous coinages from the French,German, and other languages into a Latin form made after the Latinhad become a dead language for the people.-- Law Latin, that kind of late, or low, Latin, used in statutes andlegal instruments; -- often barbarous.

The sparingly fossiliferous conglomerates, grits, schists, andstates of Great Britain, which lie at the base of the Cambriansystem; -- so called, because typically developed in the LongmyndHills, Shropshire.
Of or pertaining to the lores.
A large ornamental drinking vessel having two or more handles,intended to pass from hand to hand, as at a banquet.
A condition in which fat occurs in the blood.
Inflammation of the larynx.
A camp, esp. one with an inclosure of travelers' wagons fortemporary defense. [South Africa]
The state or quality of being level.
A procuress. J. Webster.

Pertaining to, or derived from, the European bay or laurel(Laurus nobilis). Lauric acid (Chem.), a white, crystallinesubstance, C12H24O2, resembling palmitic acid, and obtained from thefruit of the bay tree, and other sources.

Of, pertaining to or used for, setting, bringing, or going, onshore. Landing charges, charges or fees paid on goods unloaded from avessel.-- Landing net, a small, bag-shaped net, used in fishing to take thefish from the water after being hooked.-- Landing stage, a floating platform attached at one end to a wharfin such a manner as to rise and fall with the tide, and thusfacilitate passage between the wharf and a vessel lying beside thestage.-- Landing waiter, a customhouse officer who oversees the landing ofgoods, etc., from vessels; a landwaiter.
Having a structure consisting of laminæ, or thin layers.
A spot or fleck on the sun brighter than the surroundingsurface.
Laborious. [Obs.] Wyatt.-- La"bor*ous*ly, adv. [Obs.] Sir T. Elyot.
Abounding in ledges; consisting of a ledge or reef; as, a ledgyisland.
Not involving labor; not laborious; easy.
, a form of the imp. & p. p. of Light.
A person affected by lunacy; an insane person, esp. one who haslucid intervals; a madman; a person of unsound mind.The lunatic, the lover, and the poet, Are of imagination all compact.Shak.
Having white, delicate hands.
The inner corona. [R.]
A nitrogenous organic base obtained by the oxidation ofamarine, and regarded as a derivative of benzoic aldehyde. It isobtained in long white crystalline tufts, -- whence its name.
Leprosy.
Covered with thin, scurfy scales.
A diminutive lacinia.
divination practiced with water in a basin, by throwing threestones into it, and invoking the demon whose aid was sought.
Luciferian; satanic. [Obs.] Marston.

A South American ruminant (Auchenia llama), allied to thecamels, but much smaller and without a hump. It is supposed to be adomesticated variety of the guanaco. It was formerly much used as abeast of burden in the Andes.
. Amboyna wood.
Lightning. [Obs.] Spenser. Levin brand, a thunderbolt. [Obs.]Spenser.
A perennial herb (Phryma Leptostachya), having slender seedlikefruits.
One who is engaged in lumbering as a business or employment.[U.S.]

A genus of mosslike plants, the type of the order Lycopodiaceæ;club moss. Lycopodium powder, a fine powder or dust composed of thespores of Lycopodium, and other plants of the order Lycopodiaceæ. Itis highly inflammable, and is sometimes used in the manufacture offireworks, and the artificial representation of lightning.

A barking. [Obs.]
Leaper; ropedancer. [Obs.]
Indicating place, or the place where, or wherein; as, alocative adjective; locative case of a noun.-- n.
Same as Phylactolemata.

Pertaining to, or derived from, linoleum, or linseed oil;specifically (Chem.), designating an organic acid, a thin yellow oil,found combined as a salt of glycerin in oils of linseed, poppy, hemp,and certain nuts.
In a lineal manner; as, the prince is lineally descended fromthe Conqueror.
Pecuniarily embarrassed through owning much unprofitable land.[Colloq.]
An albino. [Also written leucoethiops.]
A prison. [Obs.] Hudibras.
A tumor consisting of fat or adipose tissue.-- Li*pom"a*tous, a.
A bird having lobate toes; esp., a phalarope.
A public executioner. [Scot.]
Same as Lithontriptic.
of Lie, to recline.
Of or pertaining to Libya, the ancient name of that part ofAfrica between Egypt and the Atlantic Ocean, or of Africa as a whole.

A diminution or softening of statement for the sake of avoidingcensure or increasing the effect by contrast with the moderationshown in the form of expression; as, " a citizen of no mean city,"that is, of an illustrious city.
A privy, or water-closet, esp. in a camp, hospital, etc.
Pleasing; delightful. [Obs.]
The portion of movable estate to which the children areentitled upon the death of the father.
Ornamentation by means of lacquer painted or carved, or simplycolored, sprinkled with gold or the like; -- said especially ofOriental work of this kind.
Swarming and devastating like locusts. [R.] Tennyson.
In a logical manner; as, to argue logically.

Subsistence or living, as dependent on some means of support;support of life; maintenance.The opportunities of gaining an honest livelihood. Addison.It is their profession and livelihood to get their living bypractices for which they deserve to forfeit their lives. South.
A swivel at one end of a ropewalk, used in laying the strands.
A young or small lion.
To become loose; to become less tight, firm, or compact. S.Sharp.

A chronic nervous affection of cattle, horses, and sheep,caused by eating the loco weed and characterized by a slow, measuredgait, high step, glassy eyes with defective vision, delirium, andgradual emaciation.
The art or practice of defining words; definition of words.

A genus of large and very beautiful trees of North America,having smooth, shining leaves, and handsome, tuliplike flowers; tuliptree; whitewood; -- called also canoewood. Liriodendron tulipifera isthe only extant species, but there were several others in theCretaceous epoch.
Given to the use of the tongue; loquacious. [Obs.]
Producing grief; saddening. [Obs.] Sir G. Buck.
Pertaining to liberty, or to the doctrine of free will, asopposed to the doctrine of necessity.
The period of a synodic revolution of the moon, or the timefrom one new moon to the next; varying in length, at different times,from about 29
To make lethargic.All bitters are poison, and act by stilling, and depressing, andlethargizing the irritability. Coleridge.
Of or pertaining to latitude; in the direction of latitude.
One who, or that which, licks. Licker in (Carding Machine), thedrum, or cylinder, by which the lap is taken from the feed rollers.
The state of being a laird; an estate; landed property. [Scot.]Ramsay.

An eel-like marsipobranch of the genus Petromyzon, and alliedgenera. The lampreys have a round, sucking mouth, without jaws, butset with numerous minute teeth, and one to three larger teeth on thepalate (see Illust. of Cyclostomi). There are seven small branchialopenings on each side. [Written also lamper eel, lamprel, andlampron.]
A werewolf; a lycanthrope.
Having smooth, or nearly smooth, hair.
One who lauds.
The quality or state of being luminous; luminousness.
An old name for a fossil club moss.
Inflammation of the pia mater or of the arachnoid membrane.
An upright piece of round timber, in a whaleboat, over which aturn of the line is taken when it is running out too fast. Ham. Nav.Encyc.
A nearly opaque white mineral, in part identical with titanite,observed in some igneous rocks as the result of the alteration oftitanic iron.
