of Leap. Leaped. Chaucer.
That can be lacerated or torn.
Giving light; affording light or means of discovery. Boyle.
The quality or state of being limp.
A flea.[Obs.] Cleveland.
Destitute of a lock.
Somewhat loose.
To yield; to stop; to cease. [Obs. or Scot.] Marsion.
The terminal part of the cochlea in birds and most reptiles; anappendage of the sacculus, corresponding to the cochlea, in fishesand amphibians.
A dancer of the lavolta.
Maine; -- a nickname.
Ordinary camphor; -- so called in allusion to the family name(Lauraceæ) of the camphor trees. See Camphor.
The state or quality of being libidinous; libidinousness.Skelton.
Unemployed; as, leisure hours.
Soreness of eyes; the state of being blear-eyes; blearedness.
A sacrifice, or ceremony, by which cities, fields, armies, orpeople, defiled by crimes, pestilence, or other cause of uncleanness,were purified.
Having thin, transparent, reticulated wings; as, the lace-winged flies.
Excision of the larynx.
In a lowering manner; with cloudiness or threatening gloom.
Same as Lattice, n., 1.

A game of ball, originating among the North American Indians,now the popular field sport of Canada, and played also in England andthe United States. Each player carries a long-handled racket, calleda "crosse". The ball is not handled but caught with the crosse andcarried on it, or tossed from it, the object being to carry it orthrow it through one of the goals placed at opposite ends of thefield.
Loose; lascivious. [Obs.] "To depaint lascious wantonness."Holland.
In a labial manner; with, or by means of, the lips.
Having but little sense or shrewdness.
In a lying manner; falsely.
To laugh. [Obs.] Shak.
A lad; a male sweetheart. [Scot.]
To cause to dr [Obs.] Shak. Dryden.
Inflammation of the lymphatic vessels. [Written alsolymphangitis.]
Of or pertaining to the lynx.
A small narrow opening or window in a tower or fortified wall;a loophole.
A violet dye derived from aniline.
Sipping; touching lightly. [R.] Landor.
Pertaining to libation.
Forsaken by one's love.The lovelorn nightingale. Milton.
The trapezohedron or tetragonal trisoctahedron; -- so called asbeing the form of the mineral leucite.

The inner bark of plants, lying next to the wood. It usuallycontains a large proportion of woody, fibrous cells, and is,therefore, the part from which the fiber of the plant is obtained, asthat of hemp, etc. Liber cells, elongated woody cells found in theliber.
See Leme. [Obs.] Chaucer.
Masked; hence, concealed; obscure; -- applied in medicine todoubtful cases of some diseases; as, larvate pneumonis; larvateepilepsy.
An accomplice; a "pal." [Obs.]There is no thief without a louk. Chaucer.
A meadow or sward land; a grassy field. "Plow-torn leas." Shak.The lowing herd wind slowly o'er the lea. Gray.

The arc or portion of the equator intersected between themeridian of a given place and the meridian of some other place fromwhich longitude is reckoned, as from Greenwich, England, or sometimesfrom the capital of a country, as from Washington or Paris. Thelongitude of a place is expressed either in degrees or in time; as,that of New York is 74º or 4 h. 56 min. west of Greenwich.
A minute and tedious discourse on trifling things.
A limb. [Obs.] Chaucer.
In a litigious manner.
Eagerly desirous. See Lickerish. [Obs.] Marston.
An instrument for measuring the water that percolates through acertain depth of soil. Knight.
An animal, particularly a log, having an uncut tail. Cf.Curtail. Dog.

See Graylag. Lag of the tide, the interval by which the time ofhigh water falls behind the mean time, in the first and thirdquarters of the moon; -- opposed to priming of the tide, or theacceleration of the time of high water, in the second and fourthquarters; depending on the relative positions of the sun and moon.-- Lag screw, an iron bolt with a square head, a sharp-edged thread,and a sharp point, adapted for screwing into wood; a screw forfastening lags.
An Australian myrtaceous tree (Eugenia Smithii), having smoothovate leaves, and panicles of small white flowers. The wood is hardand fine-grained.
Piercing; seeming to pierce or stab; as, lancinating pains(i.e., severe, darting pains).
Connecticut; -- a nickname alluding to the moral character ofits inhabitants, implied by the rigid laws (see Blue laws) of theearly period.
A description of the lymphatic vessels, their origin and uses.
Flattery; deceit; trickery. [Obs.] Chaucer.
An instrument, consisting of an arrangement of two mirrors, forreflecting light upon the larynx, and for examining its image.
A genus of coleopterous insects, including the glowworms.
The man who heaves the lead. Totten.
One of the divisions of a compound leaf; a foliole.

The beautiful and highly elastic wood of a tree of the genusBrosimum (B. Aubletii), found in Guiana; -- so called from blackspots in it which bear some resemblance to hieroglyphics; also calledsnakewood, and leopardwood. It is much used for bows and for walkingsticks.

A piece of glass, or other transparent substance, ground withtwo opposite regular surfaces, either both curved, or one curved andthe other plane, and commonly used, either singly or combined, inoptical instruments, for changing the direction of rays of light, andthus magnifying objects, or otherwise modifying vision. In practice,the curved surfaces are usually spherical, though rarely cylindrical,or of some other figure. Lenses
A tuft of hair; a flock or small quantity of wool, hay, orother like substance; a tress or ringlet of hair.These gray locks, the pursuivants of death. Shak.
Mourned for; bewailed.This humble praise,lamented shade ! receive. Pope.
To send out leaves; to leaf; -- often with out. G. Fletcher.
. A hospital for the treatment of venereal diseases. [Eng.]
The line by which a fowling net was pulled over so as toinclose the birds.

The state, or quality, of being legitimate, or in conformitywith law; hence, the condition of having been lawfully begotten, orborn in wedlock.The doctrine of Divine Right, which has now come back to us, like athief from transportation, under the alias of Legitimacy. Macaulay.
A white crystalline substance extracted from the fruit of thebay (Laurus nobilis), and consisting of a complex mixture of glycerinethers of several organic acids.
Of, pertaining to, or derived from, lactone.
See Lotion. [Obs.] Holland.
One who, or that which, liberates; a deliverer.

A mixture of sand, clay, and other materials, used in makingmolds for large castings, often without a pattern. Loam mold(Founding), a mold made with loam. See Loam, n., 2.-- Loam molding, the process or business of making loam molds. Loamplate, an iron plate upon which a section of a loam mold rests, orfrom which it is suspended.-- Loam work, loam molding or loam molds.
One affected by the disease lycanthropy.
of Lie, to tell a falsehood.
A kind of stereotype plate made by lithotypy; also, that whichin printed from it. See Lithotypy.
To tear; to lacerate; to pierce or stab. De Quincey.
Lit., wreath of songs; -- used as the title of a group ofsongs, and esp. as the common name for German vocal clubs of men.
To make a sound as if moving heavily or clumsily; to rumble.Cowper.
A goddess who protected newborn infants.
Typhus fever.
Same as Laverock.
Any bryozoan of the genus Lunulites, having a more or lesscircular form.

The expanded upper end of the windpipe or trachea, connectedwith the hyoid bone or cartilage. It contains the vocal cords, whichproduce the voice by their vibrations, when they are stretched and acurrent of air passes between them. The larynx is connected with thepharynx by an opening, the glottis, which, in mammals, is protectedby a lidlike epiglottis.
Toward the land.
An opera glass; pl.
Leafless. [Obs.] Carew.
An instrument used for cutting the bladder in operations forthe stone.
Permitting liquids to pass by percolation; not capable ofretaining water; porous; pervious; -- said of gravelly or sandysoils, and the like.

The art or operation of using a leveling instrument for findinga horizontal line, for ascertaining the differences of level betweendifferent points of the earth's surface included in a survey, forestablishing grades, etc., as in finding the descent of a river, orlocating a line of railroad. Leveling instrument. See Surveyor'slevel, under Level, n.-- Leveling staff, a graduated rod or staff used in connection witha leveling instrument for measuring differences of level betweenpoints.
Little. [Obs.] Chaucer.
A red color.[Obs.] Spenser.
The discharge from the womb and vagina which followschildbirth.
See Lozenge.
Affectedly pensive; languidly sentimental.-- Lack`a*dai"si*cal*ly, adv.
See under Low.
of Leave.

Of or pertaining to milk; procured from sour milk or whey; as,lactic acid; lactic fermentation, etc. Lactic acid (Physiol. Chem.),a sirupy, colorless fluid, soluble in water, with an intensely sourtaste and strong acid reaction. There are at least three isomericmodifications all having the formula C3H6O3. Sarcolactic orparalactic acid occurs chiefly in dead muscle tissue, while ordinarylactic acid results from fermentation. The two acids are alike inhaving the same constitution (expressed by the name ethylidene lacticacid), but the latter is optically inactive, while sarcolactic acidrotates the plane of polarization to the right. The third acid,ethylene lactic acid, accompanies sarcolactic acid in the juice offlesh, and is optically inactive.-- Lactic ferment, an organized ferment (Bacterium lacticum orlactis), which produces lactic fermentation, decomposing the sugar ofmilk into carbonic and lactic acids, the latter, of which renders themilk sour, and precipitates the casein, thus giving rise to the so-called spontaneous coagulation of milk.-- Lactic fermentation. See under Fermentation.
Saving labor; adapted to supersede or diminish the labor ofmen; as, laborsaving machinery.
To communicate by language; to express in language.Others were languaged in such doubtful expressions that they have adouble sense. Fuller.
A laver. [Obs.] Chaucer.
The quality of being labial; as, the labialism of anarticulation; conversion into a labial, as of a sound which isdifferent in another language. J. Peile.
The resolution or favorable termination of a disease, coming ongradually and not marked by abrupt change.

The art or process of putting designs or writing, with a greasymaterial, on stone, and of producing printed impressions therefrom.The process depends, in the main, upon the antipathy between greaseand water, which prevents a printing ink containing oil from adheringto wetted parts of the stone not covered by the design. SeeLithographic limestone, under Lithographic.
A lawyer. [Obs.] Bale.
A small cart or wagon, as those used on the tramways in minesto carry coal or rubbish; also, a barrow or truck for shiftingbaggage, as at railway stations.
A manumitted slave; a freedman; also, the son of a freedman.
Unsettled; unsteady; volatile; not considerate.-- Light"-mind`ed*ness, n.

Any one of numerous species of long-winged, migratory,orthopterous insects, of the family Acrididæ, allied to thegrasshoppers; esp., (Edipoda, or Pachytylus, migratoria, and Acridiumperigrinum, of Southern Europe, Asia, and Africa. In the UnitedStates the related species with similar habits are usually calledgrasshoppers. See Grasshopper.
Pertaining to, or like, Limax, or the slugs.

A valve gear, consisting of two eccentrics with their rods,giving motion to a slide valve by an adjustable connecting bar,called the link, in such a way that the motion of the engine can bereversed, or the cut-off varied, at will; -- used very generally inlocomotives and marine engines.
Generous; ample; liberal. [Obs.]
2d pers. sing. pres. of Lige, to lie, to tell lies, --contracted for ligest. Chaucer.
Laserwort.

A tough, elastic wood, often used for the shafts of gigs,archery bows, fishing rods, and the like. Also, the tree whichproduces this wood, Duguetia Quitarensis (a native of Guiana andCuba), and several other trees of the same family (Anonaseæ).Australian lancewood, a myrtaceous tree (Backhousia Australis).
Fitted to cause loathing; exciting disgust; disgusting.The most loathsome and deadly forms of infection. Macaulay.-- Loath"some*ly. adv.-- Loath"some*ness, n.

A milky or colored juice in certain plants in cavities (calledlatex cells or latex tubes). It contains the peculiar principles ofthe plants, whether aromatic, bitter, or acid, and in many instancesyields caoutchouc upon coagulation.
To render liquid.
One who lends.The borrower is servant to the lender. Prov. xxii. 7.
To attend to. [Obs.] Shak.
A fat, ungainly, stupid person; an awkward bungler. [Law.]
Pilotage. [Obs.]
A follower of Jean de Labadie, a religious teacher of the 17thcentury, who left the Roman Catholic Church and taught a kind ofmysticism, and the obligation of community of property amongChristians.
3d pers. sing. pres. of Lie, to recline, for lieth. Chaucer.

A small American ericaceous shrub (Kalmia angustifolia); --called also calfkill, sheepkill, sheep laurel, etc. It is supposed topoison sheep and other animals that eat it at times when the snow isdeep and they cannot find other food.

Pertaining to, or designating, certain compounds of cobalthaving a yellow color. Cf. Cobaltic. Luteocobaltic chloride (Chem.),a brilliant reddish yellow crystalline compound, Co2Cl6(NH3)12,obtained by the action of ammonium chloride on an ammoniacal solutionof cobaltic chloride.
An officer who commanded a company; a captain. Mitford.
Quality of being limpid; limpidity.
An animal base or alkaloid, appearing in the tissue duringlife; hence, a vital alkaloid, as distinguished from a ptomaine orcadaveric poison.
Slow or slowly; -- more so than adagio; next in slowness tograve, which is also weighty and solemn.-- n.

Noninterference; -- an axiom of some political economists,deprecating interference of government by attempts to foster orregulate commerce, manufactures, etc., by bounty or by restriction;as, the doctrine of laissez faire; the laissez faire systemgovernment.
Furnished with lobes or flaps.
. The fourth Sunday of Lent; -- so named from the Latin wordLætare (rejoice), the first word in the antiphone of the introit sungthat day in the Roman Catholic service.
A railway sleeper lying parallel with the rail.
One of a mongrel breed of dogs said to have been a crossbetween the sheep dog, greyhound, and spaniel. It hunts gamesilently, by scent, and is often used by poachers.
The quality of being laxative.
A white, crystalline substance, having a bitter taste and aneutral reaction, and forming one of the essential ingredients oflactucarium.
One who leaves, or withdraws.
The rank or position of a lady; -- given as a title (precededby her or your.)Your ladyship shall observe their gravity. B. Jonson.
An insect of the genus Lampyris, or family Lampyridæ. SeeLampyris.
The sound of the voice as heard through a stethoscope when thelatter is placed upon the larynx.
Unwillingness; reluctance.A general silence and loathness to speak. Bacon.
A peculiar fatlike body, made up of cholesterin and certainfatty acids, found in feathers, hair, wool, and keratin tissuesgenerally.
Of or pertaining to Lamaism.
Leafy. [Obs.] Chapman.
A lackey. [Obs.] Evelyn.
A person who adheres to his sovereign or to the lawfulauthority; especially, one who maintains his allegiance to his princeor government, and defends his cause in times of revolt orrevolution.
Growing from the stem by the side of a leaf; as, alaterifolious flower.
A man given to lewdness; one addicted, in an excessive degree,to the indulgence of sexual desire, or to illicit commerce withwomen.

The act of lying; falsehood; a lie or lies. [Archaic] Spenser.Thou shalt destroy them that speak leasing. Ps. v. 6.Blessed be the lips that such a leasing told. Fairfax.Leasing making (Scots Law), the uttering of lies or libels upon thepersonal character of the sovereign, his court, or his family. Bp.Burnet.
To strike with repeated blows for punishment; to flog; to whipor conquer, as in a pugilistic encounter. [Colloq. or Low] Carlyle.Thackeray.
Of the age of the Lias; pertaining to the Lias Formation.-- n.
Killed, wounded, and captured persons, or captured property.
Lengthwise. Addison.
A small lobe; a lobule.
Bordered, as when one color is surrounded by an edging ofanother.
See Lends. [Obs.] Chaucer.
A mirror made of glass on which has been placed a backing ofsome reflecting substance, as quicksilver.There is none so homely but loves a looking-glass. South.
To beat, as with a thong of leather. [Obs. or Colloq.] G.Eliot.
An order of Reptilia, which includes the lizards.

A solemn form of supplication in the public worship of variouschurches, in which the clergy and congregation join, the formerleading and the latter responding in alternate sentences. It isusually of a penitential character.Supplications . . . for the appeasing of God's wrath were of theGreek church termed litanies, and rogations of the Latin. Hooker.
The state of an albino, or of a white child of black parents.
A colorless, crystalline, organic base, obtained fromrosaniline by reduction, and also from other sources. It formscolorless salts.
With a lisp; in a lisping manner.
The state or quality of being laic; the state or condition of alayman.
A fibrous and muscular band lying within the longitudinal axisof the tongue in many mammals, as the dog.
A mineral of an olive-green color, commonly in orthorhombiccrystals. It is a hydrous phosphate of copper.
One who occupies himself with literature; a literary man; aliteratus. " Befriended by one kind-hearted littérateur afteranother." C. Kingsley.
A tube for producing Lenard rays.
A wolf (Canis pallipes), found in India, allied to the jackal.
A broad stripe of purple on the fore part of the tunic, worn bysenators in ancient Rome as an emblem of office.
See Lieutenancy. [Obs.]
Having no limits; unbounded; boundless. Davies (Wit's Pilgr.).
Dregs. See 2d Lee.
Urine. [Prov. Eng.] Nares.
A pasture. [Obs.]
Formed into a legion or legions; legionary. Shelley.
Toward or on the left side.Rightward and leftward rise the rocks. Southey.
An instrument for ligating, or for placing and fastening aligature.
The quality or state of being laminable.
The state or quality of being lazy.Laziness travels so slowly, that Poverty soon overtakes him.Franklin.
Bearing or containing milk or a milky fluid; as, thelactiferous vessels, cells, or tissue of various vascular plants.
Same as Loadstone.
An interpreter. [Obs.] Coke.
To be fastened with a lace, or laces; as, these boots lace.
A strap for tightening a saddle girth. [Western U. S. & Sp.Amer.]
Born in a low condition or rank; -- opposed to highborn.

One of a number of riotous persons in England, who for sixyears (1811-17) tried to prevent the use of labor-saving machinery bybreaking it, burning factories, etc.; -- so called from Ned Lud, ahalf-witted man who some years previously had broken stocking frames.J. & H. Smith. H. Martineau.
With delay; slowly; tediously.
See Lamprey.
To become lank; to make lank. [Obs.] Shak. G. Fletcher.
An explosive compound of nitroglycerin. See Nitroglycerin.
To vibrate as a balance does before resting in equilibrium;hence, to be poised.Their parts all liberate on too nice a beam. Clifton.
A native or inhabitant of London. Shak.
The act of loricating; the protecting substance put on; acovering of scales or plates.
Destitute of limbs.
To beat in the game of loo by winning every trick. [Writtenalso lu.] Goldsmith.
Having a certain look or appearance; -- often compounded withadjectives; as, good-looking, grand-looking, etc.
A layman authorized to read parts of the public service of thechurch.
To beat or flog soundly. [Prov. Eng. & Colloq. U.S.] Forby.
A system of signaling in which balls of red and green fire arefired from a pistol, the arrangement in groups denoting numbershaving a code significance.
In a lucrative manner.
To convert into wood or into a ligneous substance.
A small European rodent (Eliomys nitela), allied to thedormouse.
A lewd person. [Obs.] Shak.
To besiege; to beleaguer. [Obs.]
A concealed hiding place; a burrow; a lair; a hole.
The European meadow pipit; -- called also titling.
Destitute of light; dark. Shak.

A trade name applied somewhat indefinitely to some of thevolatile products obtained in refining crude petroleum. It is acomplex and variable mixture of several hydrocarbons, generally boilsbelow 170º Fahr., and is more inflammable than safe kerosene. It isused as a solvent, as a carburetant for air gas, and for illuminationin special lamps.
The knapweed.
Producing light. Grew.
The art, process, or occupation of making a lexicon ordictionary; the principles which are applied in making dictionaries.
In the manner of a liturgy.
In a lolling manner. Buckle.
See Lucern, the plant.
A piece of wood, shell, stone, or other substance, worn in aperforation of the lip or cheek by many savages.
A little lobule, or subdivision of a lobule.
State of being lusty; vigor of body. " Full of lustihood."Tennyson.
A change in the character of a cell wall, by which it becomesharder. It is supposed to be due to an incrustation of lignin.
Languishment. [Obs.]
Enacting laws; legislative.-- n.
The Pomeranian or Spitz dog.
In manner to excite love; amiably. [R.] Otway.
See Lecher, n. Marston.
A hypothetical radical of glycerin. [Obs.] Berzelius.
The act or process of litigating; a suit at law; a judicialcontest.
Consisting of, or abounding in, very minute laciniæ.
Sport or freak of nature; a deformed or unnatural production.
The Latin tongue, style, or idiom, or the use thereof;specifically, purity of Latin style or idiom. "His eleLatinity."Motley.
Pertaining to, or involved in, the doctrines of Lamarckianism.
Land. [Obs.] Chaucer.
The highest kind of worship, or that paid to God; --distinguished by the Roman Catholics from dulia, or the inferiorworship paid to saints.
Shaped like a bottle or flask; flag-shaped.
The act or method of luting vessels.
An earthworm, or a worm resembling an earthworm.
A writing composed of words not having a certain letters; -- asin the Odyssey of Tryphiodorus there was no A in the first book, no Bin the second, and so on.
A native sailor, employed in European vessels; also, a menialemployed about arsenals, camps, camps, etc.; a camp follower. [EastIndies]
A thin plate or lamina. [Obs.] Chaucer.
A northern constellation, the Harp, containing a white star ofthe first magnitude, called Alpha Lyræ, or Vega.
Forked, with the points slightly curved outward.

A genus of trees including, according to modern authors, onlythe true laurel (Laurus nobilis), and the larger L. Canariensis ofMadeira and the Canary Islands. Formerly the sassafras, the camphortree, the cinnamon tree, and several other aromatic trees and shrubs,were also referred to the genus Laurus.
See Sundew.

A genus of plants, including a great number of species. Lobeliainflata, or Indian tobacco, is an annual plant of North America,whose leaves contain a poisonous white viscid juice, of an acridtaste. It has often been used in medicine as an emetic, expectorant,etc. L. cardinalis is the cardinal flower, remarkable for the deepand vivid red color of its flowers.
A genus of very large fossil amphibians, of the Triassicperiod, having bony plates on the under side of the body. It is thetype of the order Labyrinthodonta. Called also Mastodonsaurus.
A lubber. [Obs.] Swift.
A low fellow. [Obs.]
Tending to become liquid; inclined to melt to melt; melting.
An evergreen shrub, of the genus Laurus (L. nobilis), havingaromatic leaves of a lanceolate shape, with clusters of small,yellowish white flowers in their axils; -- called also sweet bay.

Mineral coal retaining the texture of the wood from which itwas formed, and burning with an empyreumatic odor. It is of morerecent origin than the anthracite and bituminous coal of the propercoal series. Called also brown coal, wood coal.
To melt; to become liquid. [Obs.] Woodward.
The Hawaiian name for seaweeds. Over sixty kinds are used asfood, and have species names, as Limu Lipoa, Limu palawai, etc.
The condition or quality of being lean.
To let fall heavily or lazily.And their poor jades Lob down their heads. Shak.To lob a ball (Lawn Tennis), to strike a ball so as to send it upinto the air.
A hydrated arseniate of copper, occurring in obtuse pyramidalcrystals of a sky-blue or verdigris-green color.
Having the quality of, or used for, dissolving or destroyingstone in the bladder or kidneys; as, lithontriptic forcéps.-- n.
Consisting of loam; partaking of the nature of loam; resemblingloam. Bacon.
A resident ambassador. [Obs.] See Leger. Denham.
An apparatus, made in very various forms, and of variousmaterials, for saving one from drowning by buoying up the body whilein the water.-- Life"-pre*serv`ing, a.
One who, or that which, liberalizes. Emerson.
An alligator. [Obs.] Sir W. Raleigh.
A velvet smoothing brush. Knight.
In all probability; probably.While man was innocent he was likely ignorant of nothing thatimported him to know. Glanvill.
See Litchi.
Having the form of a lozenge or rhomb.The lozenged panes of a very small latticed window. C. Bronté.

A large marine annelid (Arenicola marina) having a row oftufted gills along each side of the back. It is found burrowing insandy beaches, both in America and Europe, and is used for bait byEuropean fishermen. Called also lobworm, and baitworm.

A hurt; an injury. Specifically:(a) (Civil Law) Loss sustained from failure to fulfill a bargain orcontract. Burrill.(b) (Med.) Any morbid change in the exercise of functions or thetexture of organs. Dunglison.
A quartzose trachyte; rhyolite.
The state of being leafy.
Tending, or serving, to liberate. [R.]
Of or pertaining to the Leiotrichi.-- n.

The lowest class of Vertebrata, including only the Amphioxus.The heart is represented only by a simple pulsating vessel. The bloodis colorless; the brain, renal organs, and limbs are wanting, and thebackbone is represented only by a simple, unsegmented notochord. SeeAmphioxus. [Written also Leptocardii.]

Being without luck; unpropitious; unfortunate; unlucky; meetingwith ill success or bad fortune; as, a luckless gamester; a lucklessmaid.Prayers made and granted in a luckless hour. Dryden.-- Luck"less*ly, adv.-- Lock"less*ness, n.
An automobile body with seats and permanent top like a coupé,and with the top projecting over the driver and a projecting front;also, an automobile with such a body.
Characterized by leisure; taking abundant tome; not hurried;as, a leisurely manner; a leisurely walk.
See Alexipharmic.
The quality of being lenitive.
At leisure. [Obs.]
Long-loved; longevous.[R.] Pope.
Likely or inclined to roll or pitch, as a ship in a heavy sea;having a tendency to labor.
White-livered; cowardly.
The string that fastens a shoe; a shoestring.
. The act or practice by private persons of inflictingpunishment for crimes or offenses, without due process of law.

A lawgiver; one who makes laws for a state or community; amember of a legislative body.The legislators in ancient and heroical times. Bacon.Many of the legislators themselves had taken an oath of abjuration ofhis Majesty's person and family. E. Phillips.

A border or edge, in certain special uses.(a) (Bot.) The border or upper spreading part of a monopetalouscorolla, or of a petal, or sepal; blade.(b) (Astron.) The border or edge of the disk of a heavenly body,especially of the sun and moon.(c) The graduated margin of an arc or circle, in an instrument formeasuring angles.

Print; letters and words impressed on paper or other materialby types; -- often used of the reading matter in distinction from theillustrations.Letterpress printing, printing directly from type, in distinctionfrom printing from plates.
A direction in written or printed music to return to the properpitch after having played an octave higher.
An organic residue or radical derived from lactic acid.
Pertaining to Lusitania, the ancient name of the region almostcoinciding with Portugal.-- n.
Heather (Calluna vulgaris). Ling honey, a sort of wild honey,made from the flowers of the heather. Holland.
An abject flatterer or parasite. Theodore Hook.

Crossing the line of a ship's course in a favorable direction;-- said of the wind when it is abeam, or between the beam and thequarter. At large. (a) Without restraint or confinement; as, to go atlarge; to be left at large. (b) Diffusely; fully; in the full extent;as, to discourse on a subject at large.-- Common at large. See under Common, n.-- Electors at large, Representative at large, electors, or arepresentative, as in Congress, chosen to represent the whole of aState, in distinction from those chosen to represent particulardistricts in a State. [U. S.] -- To give, go, run, or sail large(Naut.), to have the wind crossing the direction of a vessel's coursein such a way that the sails feel its full force, and the vesselgains its highest speed. See Large, a., 8.
Any plant of the umbelliferous genus Laserpitium, of severalspecies (as L. glabrum, and L. siler), the root of which yields aresinous substance of a bitter taste. The genus is mostly European.
Of or pertaining to lithophytes.
A group of shore birds, embracing the plovers, sandpipers,snipe, curlew, etc. ; the Grallæ.
Having a dense covering of long hair, like the foot of a hare.
Containing, or intended to contain, tears; lachrymal. Addison.

A composite plant of the genus Lactuca (L. sativa), the leavesof which are used as salad. Plants of this genus yield a milky juice,from which lactucarium is obtained. The commonest wild lettuce of theUnited States is L. Canadensis. Hare's lettuce, Lamb's lettuce. Seeunder Hare, and Lamb.-- Lettuce opium. See Lactucarium.-- Sea lettuce, certain papery green seaweeds of the genus Ulva.
Same as Lofter.
Foil or wire made of gold, silver, or brass. De Colange.

One of the elements, a heavy, pliable, inelastic metal, havinga bright, bluish color, but easily tarnished. It is both malleableand ductile, though with little tenacity, and is used for tubes,sheets, bullets, etc. Its specific gravity is 11.37. It is easilyfusible, forms alloys with other metals, and is an ingredient ofsolder and type metal. Atomic weight, 206.4. Symbol Pb (L. Plumbum).It is chiefly obtained from the mineral galena, lead sulphide.
Furnished with lapels.
In a lifelike manner. [Obs.] Chaucer.
Containing or involving a libel; defamatory; containing thatwhich exposes some person to public hatred, contempt, or ridicule;as, a libelous pamphlet. [Written also libellous.] -- Li"bel*ous*ly,adv.
A metallic element of the alkaline group, occurring in severalminerals, as petalite, spodumene, lepidolite, triphylite, etc., andotherwise widely disseminated, though in small quantities.

A thin, narrow strip of wood, nailed to the rafters, studs, orfloor beams of a building, for the purpose of supporting the tiles,plastering, etc. A corrugated metallic strip or plate is sometimesused. Lath brick, a long, slender brick, used in making the floor onwhich malt is placed in the drying kiln. Lath nail a slender nail forfastening laths.

In France, a name for a woman who is supported by her lovers,and devotes herself to idleness, show, and pleasure; -- so calledfrom the church of Notre Dame de Lorette, in Paris, near which manyof them resided.
Nimble; swift of foot. Sir P. Sidney.
See Louver.

Of even tone; without rising or falling inflection. H. Sweet.Level line (Shipbuilding), the outline of a section which ishorizontal crosswise, and parallel with the rabbet of the keellengthwise. Level surface (Physics), an equipotential surface atright angles at every point to the lines of force.
A branch of the Mongolian race, now living in the northernparts of Norway, Sweden, and the adjacent parts of Russia.
Any one of a division (Lepidoganoidei) of ganoid fishes,including those that have scales forming a coat of mail. Also usedadjectively.
A luncheon; specifically, a light repast between breakfast anddinner.
A whiplash. [Obs.]
The young of the sheep.
A contrivance to fasten logs together in rafting; -- used bylumbermen. [U.S.]
The act of making legal.
Having a long horn or horns; as, a long-horned goat, or cow;having long antennæ, as certain beetles (Longicornia).
Somewhat lank. Thackeray.The lanky Dinka, nearly seven feet in height. The Century.
The act of labefying or making weak; the state of beingweakened; decay; ruin.There is in it such a labefaction of all principles as may beinjurious to morality. Johnson.
A swift hound.
Loobylike; awkward. Fuller.
In a lank manner.
Somewhat late. [Colloq.]
An action at law; a suit in equity or admiralty; any legalproceeding before a court for the enforcement of a claim.
The art of cutting and engraving gems.
To tear in pieces. [R.]
, & i. To lay; to wager. [Obs.] Chaucer.
Of or pertaining to the tongue; uttered by the aid of thetongue; glossal; as, the lingual nerves; a lingual letter. Lingualribbon. (Zoöl.) See Odontophore.
Clownish; rude; awkward. "Loutish clown." Sir P. Sidney.-- Lout"ish*ly, adv.-- Lout"*ish*ness, n.
Having lobate toes, as a coot.

Of or pertaining to the isle of Lemnos. Lemnian bole, Lemnianearth, an aluminous earth of a grayish yellow color; sphragide; --formerly sold as medicine, having astringent properties.-- Lemnian reddle, a reddle of firm consistence and deep red color;-- used by artificers in coloring.
Same as Base, n., 19.
In like manner; also; moreover; too. See Also.Go, and do thou likewise. Luke x. 37.For he seeth that wise men die; likewise the fool and the brutishperson perish. Ps. xlix. 10.
See water buck, under 3d Buck.
In a linear manner; with lines.
A short right-angled pipe fitting, used in connecting two pipesat right angles. [Written also ell.]
Leprous; infectious; corrupting; poisonous. "The leperousdistillment." Shak.
A cuirass, originally of leather, afterward of plates of metalor horn sewed on linen or the like.
The American hop hornbeam (Ostrya Virginica), a small tree withvery tough wood.
White; -- applied to albinos, from the whiteness of their skinand hair.
See Lithotriptor.
Extended to a great length.The cicadæ hushed their long-drawn, ear-splitting strains. G. W.Cable.
A linen roller used in dressing wounds.
One of a tribe of beetles, having long maxillary palpi.
Linen. [Obs.] Spenser.
A fault.
Having long arms; as, the long-armed ape or gibbon.
Smallest, either in size or degree; shortest; lowest; mostunimportant; as, the least insect; the least mercy; the least space.
A system of bracing bars, not crossing each other in themiddle, connecting the channel bars of a compound strut. Waddell.
To engage in logrolling; to accomplish by logrolling.[Political cant, U. S.]
Bearing, or having, a leaf or leaves; having folds; -- used incombination; as, a four-leaved clover; a two-leaved gate; long-leaved.
, See Alarum, and Alarm.
One who lingers. Guardian.
. See under Lich.
Held by lease.
A man who deals in lace.
Damaged by accidental exposure to light; light-fogged; -- saidof plates or films.

A prefix from L. laevus, meaning:(a) Pertaining to, or toward, the left; as, levorotatory.(b) (Chem. & Opt.) Turning the plane of polarized light to the left;as, levotartaric acid; levoracemic acid; levogyratory crystals, etc.[Written also lævo-.]
The American white mullet (Mugil curema).
The quality or state of being lucid.
A form of hydrometer, specially graduated, for finding thedensity of milk, and thus discovering whether it has been mixed withwater or some of the cream has been removed.
An iron club used in lofting the ball; -- called also loftingiron.
To halt; to walk lamely. Also used figuratively. Shak.
Letter for letter.
One who leases; the person who lets to farm, or gives a lease.Blackstone.

Of or pertaining to luxury; ministering to luxury; suppliedwith the conditions of luxury; as, a luxurious life; a luxurioustable; luxurious ease. " Luxurious cities. " Milton.-- Lux*u"ri*ous*ly, adv.-- Lux*u"ri*ous*ness, n.
, Having slender toes.
Somewhat long; moderately long.

A region of British America on the Atlantic coast, north ofNewfoundland. Labrador duck (Zoöl.), a sea duck (CamtolaimusLabradorius) allied to the eider ducks. It was formerly common on thecoast of New England, but is now supposed to be extinct, no specimenshaving been reported since 1878.-- Labrador feldspar. See Labradorite.-- Labrador tea (Bot.), a name of two low, evergreen shrubs of thegenus Ledum (L. palustre and L. latifolium), found in Northern Europeand America. They are used as tea in British America, and inScandinavia as a substitute for hops.
Bearing or producing wool.

An established formula for public worship, or the entire ritualfor public worship in a church which uses prescribed forms; aformulary for public prayer or devotion. In the Roman Catholic Churchit includes all forms and services in any language, in any part ofthe world, for the celebration of Mass.
See Lazzaroni.
A mineral having a glassy fracture, occurring in translucenttrapezohedral crystals. It is a silicate of alumina and potash. It isfound in the volcanic rocks of Italy, especially at Vesuvius.
To learn. [Obs.] See Lere, to learn.
A four-wheeled covered vehicle, the top of which is dividedinto two sections which can be let down, or thrown back, in such amanner as to make an open carriage. [Written also landaw.]
The process of separating, by heat, an easily fusible metalfrom one less fusible; eliquation.

The theory that structural variations, characteristic ofspecies and genera, are produced in animals and plants by the directinfluence of physical environments, and esp., in the case of animals,by effort, or by use or disuse of certain organs.
A leopard. [Obs. or Poetic] Spenser. Keats.
A limehound; a limmer. Chaucer.
Of, pertaining to, or obtained from, lichens. Lichenic acid.(a) An organic acid, C14H24O3 obtained from Iceland moss. (b) An oldname of fumaric acid.
One who makes, inscribes, or engraves, alphabetical letters.
The art or method of sailing on the loxodromic or rhumb line.
See Laconic, a.
Having a lawn; characterized by a lawn or by lawns; like alawn.Musing through the lawny park. T. Warton.
An American genus of sapotaceous trees bearing sweet and ediblefruits.
Divided into compartments.
A combining form signifying orange yellow or brownish yellow.
A feast of the Romans in honor of Lupercus, or Pan.
Bearing or producing wool.
The act or process of covering with laths; laths, collectively;a covering of laths.
A metallic vein; any regular vein or course, whether metallicor not.
A name sometimes applied to the process of annealing metals.
A lynx. See 1st Lucern and Loup-cervier.
One who, or that which, lights; as, a lighter of lamps.
A little lad. [R.] Dr. H. More.
Forming, or separating into, scales or thin layers.
See Laund.
A group of birds embracing the Anseres and flamingoes, in whichthe bill is lamellate.
Same as Lieutenancy, 1.
The act, process, or method, of reducing a gas or vapor to aliquid by cold or pressure; as, the liquefaction of oxygen orhydrogen.
Union by league; alliance. [Obs.]
That branch of the military art which embraces the details ofmoving and supplying armies. The meaning of the word is by somewriters extended to include strategy. H. L. Scott.
A person who knowingly utters falsehood; one who lies.
A thin, flat piece of board in the form of a quadrant of acircle attached to the log line; -- called also log-ship. See 2d Log,n., 2.
To allot; to sort; to portion. [R.] To lot on or upon, to countor reckon upon; to expect with pleasure. [Colloq. U. S.]
Somewhat slow or slowly, but not so slowly as largo, and rathermore so than andante.
Land lying untilled; fallow ground. [Obs.] Blount.
To make or enact a law or laws.Solon, in legislating for the Athenians, had an idea of a moreperfect constitution than he gave them. Bp. Watson (1805).
Pertaining to, or designating, a crystalline, organic acid,resembling cholic acid, found in the biliary intestinal concretions(bezoar stones) common in certain species of antelope.
A Hebrew measure of liquids, containing 2.37 gills. W. H. Ward.
Libertinism; license. [R.]
Linsey-woolsey.
With laughter or merriment.
Of or pertaining to the larch. Keats.
Pertaining to, or like, a labyrinth; labyrinthal.
of Light, to alight. Chaucer.
A body of foot soldiers and cavalry consisting of differentnumbers at different periods, -- from about four thousand to aboutsix thousand men, -- the cavalry being about one tenth.
Same as Lycopodium powder. See under Lycopodium.

A colored, usually green, expansion growing from the side of astem or rootstock, in which the sap for the use of the plant iselaborated under the influence of light; one of the parts of a plantwhich collectively constitute its foliage.

One of a series of organic compounds, regarded as anhydrides ofcertain hydroxy acids. In general, they are colorless liquids, havinga weak aromatic odor. They are so called because the typical lactoneis derived from lactic acid.
Like. [Obs.] Chaucer.
Having ears which lop or hang down.
A chest of drawers not more than four feet high; -- appliedcommonly to the lower half of a tallboy from which the upper half hasbeen removed. [U. S.]
Disposition to bear injuries patiently; forbearance; patience.Jer. Taylor.
See Ligule.

A white, crystalline, nitrogenous substance formed in thedecomposition of albuminous matter by pancreatic digestion, by theaction of boiling dilute sulphuric acid, and by putrefaction. It isalso found as a constituent of various tissues and organs, as thespleen, pancreas, etc., and likewise in the vegetable kingdom.Chemically it is to be considered as amido-caproic acid.(CH3)2CH.CH2.CH(NH2)-COOH. L-leucine, the natural form, is present inmost proteins.
Suckling; giving suck.
Having life; -- used only in composition; as, long-lived;short-lived.
A washing or cleansing. [Obs. or R.]
To extent in length; to make longer in extent or duration; as,to lengthen a line or a road; to lengthen life; -- sometimes followedby out.What if I please to lengthen out his date. Dryden.
See Lamprey.

To cause to rest by soothing influences; to compose; to calm;to soothe; to quiet. " To lull him soft asleep." Spenser.Such sweet compulsion doth in music lie, To lull the daughters ofnecessity. Milton.
Lethean. [Obs.] Marston.
Greatness of distance; remoteness. [R.] Barrow.
A kiln or furnace in which limestone or shells are burned andreduced to lime.
Bearing only ligulate flowers; -- said of a large suborder ofcomposite plants, such as the dandelion, hawkweed, etc.
Same as Lif.

A very singular rodent (Lophiomys Imhausi) of NortheasternAfrica. It is the only known representative of a special family(Lophiomyidæ), remarkable for the structure of the skull. It hashandlike feet, and the hair is peculiar in structure and arrangement.
. See under 4th Lime.
A very brave person.
The quality or state of being lithe; flexibility; limberness.
One who lusts.

Like the genus Labrus; belonging to the family Labridæ, anextensive family of marine fishes, often brilliantly colored, whichare very abundant in the Indian and Pacific Oceans. The tautog andcunner are American examples.
Spring or source of life.
A phosphate of manganese and lithium; a variety of triphylite.
To clean from lice. "You sat and loused him." Swift.
Viscid; viscous; tenacious.Spawn of a lentous and transparent body. Sir T. Browne.
Having leisure. "The leisured classes." Gladstone.
Like a lizard; of or pertaining to the Lacertilia.-- n.
That which liquefies.
an East Indian name for several twining leguminous plantsrelated to the bean, but commonly applied to the hyacinth bean(Delichos Lablab).

Gruel; porridge; -- so called among seamen. Loblolly bay(Bot.), an elegant white-flowered evergreen shrub or small tree, ofthe genus Gordonia (G. Lasianthus), growing in the maritime parts ofthe Southern United States. Its bark is sometimes used in tanning.Also, a similar West Indian tree (Laplacea hæmatoxylon).-- Loblolly boy, a surgeon's attendant on shipboard. Smollett.-- Loblolly pine (Bot.), a kind of pitch pine found from Delawaresouthward along the coast; old field pine (Pinus Tæda). Also, P.Bahamensis, of the West Indies.-- Loblolly tree (Bot.), a name of several West Indian trees, havingmore or less leathery foliage, but alike in no other respect; asPisonia subcordata, Cordia alba, and Cupania glabra.
A looseness; diarrhea.
See Limiter, 2.

Any large macrurous crustacean used as food, esp. those of thegenus Homarus; as the American lobster (H. Americanus), and theEuropean lobster (H. vulgaris). The Norwegian lobster (NephropsNorvegicus) is similar in form. All these have a pair of largeunequal claws. The spiny lobsters of more southern waters, belongingto Palinurus, Panulirus, and allied genera, have no large claws. Thefresh-water crayfishes are sometimes called lobsters. Lobstercaterpillar (Zoöl.), the caterpillar of a European bombycid moth(Stauropus fagi); -- so called from its form. Lobster louse (Zoöl.),a copepod crustacean (Nicothoë astaci) parasitic on the gills of theEuropean lobster.
The wife of a landgrave.
Having (such) a leaf or (so many) leaves; -- used incomposition; as, broad-leafed; four-leafed.
Land held by a life estate.
. An army officer in rank next below a general and next above amajor general.
Easily bent; pliable. Lithy tree (Bot.), a European shrub(Viburnum Lantana); -- so named from its tough and flexible stem.
Of or pertaining to the spleen; splenic.

Guiding; directing; controlling; foremost; as, a leadingmotive; a leading man; a leading example.-- Lead"ing*ly, adv. Leading case (Law), a reported decision whichhas come to be regarded as settling the law of the question involved.Abbott.-- Leading motive Etym: [a translation of G. leitmotif] (Mus.), aguiding theme; in the modern music drama of Wagner, a marked melodicphrase or short passage which always accompanies the reappearance ofa certain person, situation, abstract idea, or allusion in the courseof the play; a sort of musical label.-- Leading note (Mus.), the seventh note or tone in the ascendingmajor scale; the sensible note.-- Leading question, a question so framed as to guide the personquestioned in making his reply.-- Leading strings, strings by which children are supported whenbeginning to walk.-- To be in leading strings, to be in a state of infancy ordependence, or under the guidance of others.-- Leading wheel, a wheel situated before the driving wheels of alocomotive engine.

An enzoötic, often fatal, disease of sheep and other domesticanimals, of unknown cause. It is characterized by muscular tremorsand spasms, followed by more or less complete paralysis. Theprincipal lesion is an inflammation of the membranes covering thebrain and spinal cord.
Of or pertaining to the art of cutting and engraving preciousstones.
To subject to the influence of letheon. [R. or Obs.]
Full of vitality. Spenser.
The fiber by which the petioles of the date palm are boundtogether, from which various kinds of cordage are made.

Confined within limits; narrow; circumscribed; restricted; as,our views of nature are very limited. Limited company, a company inwhich the liability of each shareholder is limited by the number ofshares he has taken, so that he can not be called on to contributebeyond the amount of his shares. [Eng.] Mozley & W.

Used in, or for, or by, lifting. Lifting bridge, a lift bridge.-- Lifting jack. See 2d Jack, 5.-- Lifting machine. See Health lift, under Health.-- Lifting pump. (Mach.) (a) A kind of pump having a bucket, orvalved piston, instead of a solid piston, for drawing water andlifting it to a high level. (b) A pump which lifts the water only tothe top of the pump, or delivers it through a spout; a lift pump.-- Lifting rod, a vertical rod lifted by a rock shaft, and impartingmotion to a puppet valve; -- used in the engines of river steamboats.-- Lifting sail (Naut.), one which tends to lift a vessel's bow outof water, as jibs and square foresails.

The fine impalpable soot obtained from the smoke ofcarbonaceous substances which have been only partly burnt, as in theflame of a smoking lamp. It consists of finely divided carbon, withsometimes a very small proportion of various impurities. It is usedas an ingredient of printers' ink, and various black pigments andcements.
One who locates, or is entitled to locate, land or a miningclaim. [U.S.]
Having a dropsical habit of body, with a white bloated skin.
To smear; to anoint. [Obs.] Shak.
An elongated pod, consisting, like the legume, of two valves,but divided transversely into small cells, each containing a singleseed.
Lenticular.
A dealer in linen; a linen draper. [Obs.]

To acquire knowledge or skill; to make progress in acquiringknowledge or skill; to receive information or instruction; as, thischild learns quickly.Take my yoke upon you and learn of me. Matt. xi. 29.To learn by heart. See By heart, under Heart.-- To learn by rote, to memorize by repetition without exercise ofthe understanding.
As lovers do.As they sat down here loverwise. W. D. Howells.
The lowest of the three divisions of the Jurassic period; aname given in England and Europe to a series of marine limestonesunderlying the Oölite. See the Chart of Geology.
To lose. [Obs.] Chaucer.
One who engages in logrolling. [Political cant, U. S.]The jobbers and logrollers will all be against it. The. Nation.
One who lisps.
The European eelpout; -- called also lumpen.
. Wine which has been kept for some time in the cellar.Simmonds.
A climbing species of Clematis (C. Vitalba).
Black and blue; grayish blue; of a lead color; discolored, asflesh by contusion. Cowper.There followed no carbuncles, no purple or livid spots, the mass ofthe blood not being tainted. Bacon.

To suffer loss, disadvantage, or defeat; to be worse off, esp.as the result of any kind of contest.We 'll . . . hear poor rogues Talk of court news; and we'll talk withthem too, Who loses and who wins; who's in, who's out. Shak.
Like a lamb; gentle; meek; inoffensive.
Leucocythæmia.
Masked; clothed as with a mask.
Long since; long ago. [Scot.]
of Lead. Led captain. An obsequious follower or attendant.[Obs.] Swift.-- Led horse, a sumpter horse, or a spare horse, that is led along.

A general name for a group of Algonquin tribes which formerlyoccupied the coast region of North America from Connecticut toVirginia. They included the Mohicans, Delawares, Shawnees, andseveral other tribes.
Having the form of a thong or strap; ligulate.
A group of longwinged sea birds, including the gulls, petrels,etc.
The act or business of putting on lacquer; also, the coat oflacquer put on.
The Pawnees, a tribe of North American Indians whose principaltotem was the wolf.
of Lie. See lain. Ps. lxviii. 13.
As a lobe; so as to make a lobe; in a lobate manner.
In a lax manner.
To subject to a washing process for the purpose of separatingsoluble material from that which is insoluble; to leach, as ashes,for the purpose of extracting the alkaline substances.
One who is loved. [Humorous] "The lover and lovee." Richardson.
Disposed to litigate; contending in law; engaged in a lawsuit;as, the parties litigant. Ayliffe.
Crazy; mentally unsound. [Written also loony.] [Law, U.S.]
Wearing a livery. See Livery, 3.The liveried servants wait. Parnell.
A writer of a lexicon. [R.]
In a lordly manner.
Exclamation of regret or surprise. [Prov. Eng.] Cowper.
Having a curved spine.
Latency. Coleridge.
The Viburnum Tinus, an evergreen shrub or tree of the south ofEurope, which flowers during the winter mouths. [Written alsolaurustine and laurestina.]
In a lousy manner; in a mean, paltry manner; scurvily. [Vulgar]
Any species of ammonites of the genus Lituites. They are foundin the Cretaceous formation.
A writ based upon the presumption that the person summoned washiding. Blackstone.
A tract of ground laid out for the game of golf; a golfinggreen.
A long lock of hair hanging prominently by itself; an earlock;-- worn by men of fashion in the reigns of Elizabeth and James I.Burton.A long lovelock and long hair he wore. Sir W. Scott.
The quality or state of being liquid; liquidity; fluency.

The melted rock ejected by a volcano from its top or fissuredsides. It flows out in streams sometimes miles in length. It alsoissues from fissures in the earth's surface, and forms beds coveringmany square miles, as in the Northwestern United States.
To impart to (one) a manner or character like that whichdistinguishes Londoners.
An assuasive. [Obs.]
Lascivious. [Obs.] Dr. H. More.
Same as Lunule.
same as Advancing edge, above.
An Italian coin equivalent in value to the French franc.
A green vegetable dye imported from China.
The art or practice of captivating the hearts of women.Better for the sake of womankind that this dangerous dog should leaveoff lady-killing. Thackeray.
Pertaining to, or kept in, the lower case; -- used to denotethe small letters, in distinction from capitals and small capitals.See the Note under 1st Case, n., 3.
A loanin. [Scot.]
The art of using the laryngoscope; investigations made with thelaryngoscope.
Lacertian.
A spiral whose polar equation is r2th = a; that is, a curve thesquare of whose radius vector varies inversely as the angle which theradius vector makes with a given line.
A hare in the first year of its age.
A liberal.
One of a class of laborers employed about the wharves of aseaport, especially in loading and unloading vessels.
Confining to the bed; as, a lectual disease.
Of or pertaining to a legate; as, legatine power. Holinshed.
An imperfect enunciation of the letter r, in which it soundslike l.

Resulting from the united action, or pertaining to the mutualrelations, of the sun and moon. Lunisolar precession (Astron.), thatportion of the annual precession of the equinoxes which depends onthe joint action of the sun and moon.-- Lunisolar year, a period of time, at the end of which, in theJulian calendar, the new and full moons and the eclipses recur on thesame days of the week and month and year as in the previous period.It consists of 532 common years, being the least common multiple ofthe numbers of years in the cycle of the sun and the cycle of themoon.
pertaining to, containing, or conveying lymph.
Same as Liege, n., 2. Chaucer. Spenser.

An expression of mirth peculiar to the human species; the soundheard in laughing; laughter. See Laugh, v. i.And the loud laugh that spoke the vacant mind. Goldsmith.That man is a bad man who has not within him the power of a heartylaugh. F. W. Robertson.

A European fish (Peristethus cataphractum), having the bodycovered with bony plates, and having three spines projecting in frontof the nose; -- called also noble, pluck, pogge, sea poacher, andarmed bullhead.

A genus of Australian gallinaceous birds including but a singlespecies (Leipoa ocellata), about the size of a turkey. Its color isvariegated, drown, black, white, and gray. Called also nativepheasant.
Having the quality of softening or mitigating, as pain oracrimony; assuasive; emollient.
A lion. [Obs.] Chaucer.
A genus of herbaceous plants including the flax (Linumusitatissimum).
See Loach.
A people visited by Ulysses in his wanderings. They subsistedon the lotus. See Lotus (b), and Lotus-eater.
Alone [Scot.] His lane, by himself; himself alone.

A dyestuff extracted from certain lichens (Roccella tinctoria,Lecanora tartarea, etc.), as a blue amorphous mass which consists ofa compound of the alkaline carbonates with certain coloring mattersrelated to orcin and orcein.
Levirate marriage or marriages. Kitto.
A glucoside found in the seeds of several species of lupine,and extracted as a yellowish white crystalline substance.
To feel disgust or nausea. [Obs.]
A contraction of the muscles of the jaw by which its motion issuspended; a variety of tetanus.
Formed or pronounced by the cooperation of the lips and teeth,as f and v.-- n.
of Last, to endure. Chaucer.
Of or pertaining to the Letts.-- n.
A substitute or deputy; one filling an office for a time.
Distance north or south of the equator, measured on a meridian.
A hydrous sulphate of lead and copper occurring in bright bluemonoclinic crystals.
Adorned with lions heads; having arms terminating in lions'heads; -- said of a cross. [Written also leonced.]
To allege; to assert. [Obs.] Bp. Fisher.
Pertaining to, or denoting, an acid (called also acetyl-propionic acid), C5H8O3, obtained by the action of dilute acids onvarious sugars (as levulose). [Written also lævulinic.]
The state of being litigious; disposition to engage in or carryon lawsuits.
One who has been fondled to excess; one fond of ease andsensual delights; -- a term of contempt.
One who plays on a lute.
Bearing, or composed of, lamellæ, or thin layers, plates, orscales; foliated.
The spikelet or flower cluster of grasses. Gray.
The first day of August; -- called also Lammas day, andLammastide.
Very brave; brave and magnanimous. Sir W. Scott.
In a lively manner. [Obs.] Lamb.
Lying or remaining in a place; hence, resident; as, legerambassador.
That part of the army, in Germany and Austria, which hascompleted the usual military service and is exempt from duty in timeof peace, except that it is called out occasionally for drill.
A dealer in, or negotiator of, loans.The millions of the loanmonger. Beaconsfield.
In a lamenting manner.
The time that life continues.
The sordid friar bird of Australia (Tropidorhynchus sordidus).
A supposed new metallic element. It is said to have beendiscovered in pyrites, and some other minerals, and to be of asilver-white color, and malleable.
To attend the levee or levees of.He levees all the great. Young.
To labialize. Brewer.
One who is skilled in lithology.
Having a language; skilled in language; -- chiefly used incomposition. " Manylanguaged nations." Pope.
A pointed forked staff, shod with iron at the foot, to hold alighted match for firing cannon. [Written also lintstock.]
A group of birds characterized by having long slender bills, asthe sandpipers, curlews, and ibises. It is now regarded as anartificial division.
One of numerous species of long-winged, shrikelike birds ofAustralia and the East Indies, of the genus Artamus, and alliedgenera; called also wood swallow.
Pertaining to, or designating, an organic amido acid, which isregarded as a derivative of lactic acid and urea.
Actinomycosis. [Colloq.]
Enacting laws; legislative.
Logicalness.
Illumination. [Obs.]
One who loses. South.
Milky; full of white juice like milk. [Obs.] "Lactary or milkyplants." Sir T. Browne.
A flatterer; a deceiver; a cozener. [Obs.] Chaucer.To a fair pair of gallows, there to end their lives with shame, as anumber of such other losengers had done. Holinshed.
The act, process, or art of one who limns; the picture ordecoration so produced.Adorned with illumination which we now call limning. Wood.
A sorry fellow; a worthless person; a rogue.
Like a lion; fierce. [Obs.] Milton.
A kind of linen cloth anciently used in England, originallyimported from Brittany. Shak.
The point of junction of the sagittal and lambdoid sutures ofthe skull. Lambda moth (Zoöl.), a moth so called from a mark on itswings, resembling the Greek letter lambda (
The operation of crushing a stone in the bladder with aninstrument called lithotriptor or lithotrite; lithotrity.
Less. [Obs.] Chaucer.
Looking; appearing; as, better or worse liking. See Like, tolook. [Obs.] Chaucer.Why should he see your faces worse liking than the children which areof your sort Dan. i. 10.
A spasmodic state of the glottis, giving rise to contraction orclosure of the opening.
To assuage; to soften; to Bacon. Dryden.
Like an earthworm; belonging to the genus Lumbricus, or familyLumbricidæ.
Pliant; limber; flexible; supple; nimble; lissom.-- Lithe"some*ness, n.
Having white or silvery foliage.
A gentle gale of wind.
A square sail bent upon a yard that hangs obliquely to the mastand is raised or lowered with the sail. Totten.
The state or quality of being lutulent.
Composing a ligament; of the nature of a ligament; binding; as,a strong ligamentous membrane.
A white organic base, resembling morphine, and obtained fromcertain varieties of opium.
A member of the lobby; a person who solicits members of alegislature for the purpose of influencing legislation. [U.S.]
The pileated woodpecker.
One who favors or adheres strictly to a liturgy. Milton.
Of or pertaining to Laconia, a division of ancient Greece;Spartan.-- n.
Lasciviousness; wantonness. [Obs.]

Of or pertaining to a peculiar rig used in the Mediterraneanand adjacent waters, esp. on the northern coast of Africa. See below.Lateen sail. Etym: [F. voile latine a sail in the shape of a right-angled triangle; cf. It. & Sp. vela latina; properly Latin sail. SeeLatin.] (Naut.) A triangular sail, extended by a long yard, which isslung at about one fourth of its length from the lower end, to a lowmast, this end being brought down at the tack, while the other end iselevated at an angle or about forty-five degrees; -- used in smallboats, feluccas, xebecs, etc., especially in the Mediterranean andadjacent waters. Some lateen sails have also a boom on the lowerside.
A treatise on stones found in the body.
A system of bars crossing in the middle to form braces betweenprincipal longitudinal members, as of a strut.
A small opening, as in the walls of fortification, or in thebulkhead of a ship, through which small arms or other weapons may bedischarged at an enemy.

The body of persons in a state or kingdom invested with powerto make and repeal laws; a legislative body.Without the concurrent consent of all three parts of the legislature,no law is, or can be, made. Sir M. Hale.
A wash or lotion. [Obs.]

A substance resembling dextrin, obtained from the bulbs of thedahlia, the artichoke, and other sources, as a colorless, spongy,amorphous material. It is so called because by decomposition ityields levulose. [Written also lævulin.]
Of full size; of the natural size.
Somewhat late; backward. [Obs.] "Lateward lands." Holland.

The state of a landlord. [Obs.]
Deficient in animation and courage; dejected; depressed; notsprightly.-- Low"-spir`it*ed*ness, n.
The quality or state of being ladylike.
A rare sulphide of osmium and ruthenium found with platinum inBorneo and Oregon.
Resembling a worm; as, the lumbrical muscles of the hands ofthe hands and feet.-- n.
Ugly; loathsome. [Prov. Eng. & Scot.]This laidly and loathsome worm. W. Howitt.
Divided into secondary compartments or cells, as where onecavity is separated into several smaller ones.

Of or pertaining to a lamp. Lucernal microscope, a form of themicroscope in which the object is illuminated by means of a lamp, andits image is thrown upon a plate of ground glass connected with theinstrument, or on a screen independent of it.

Like a line; narrow; of the same breadth throughout, except atthe extremities; as, a linear leaf. Linear differential (Math.), anequation which is of the first degree, when the expression which isequated to zero is regarded as a function of the dependent variableand its differential coefficients.-- Linear equation (Math.), an equation of the first degree betweentwo variables; -- so called because every such equation may beconsidered as representing a right line.-- Linear measure, the measurement of length.-- Linear numbers (Math.), such numbers as have relation to lengthonly: such is a number which represents one side of a plane figure.If the plane figure is square, the linear figure is called a root.-- Linear problem (Geom.), a problem which may be solvedgeometrically by the use of right lines alone.-- Linear transformation (Alg.), a change of variables where eachvariable is replaced by a function of the first degree in the newvariable.
See Lionced.
One who laves; a washer. [Obs.]
A small fishlike animal (Amphioxus lanceolatus), remarkable forthe rudimentary condition of its organs. It is the type of the classLeptocardia. See Amphioxus, Leptocardia.
Sighting or making land when at sea. A good landfall (Naut.),the sighting of land in conformity with the navigator's reckoning andexpectation.
In a lenient manner.

Lead monoxide; a yellowish red substance, obtained as anamorphous powder, or crystallized in fine scales, by heating leadmoderately in a current of air or by calcining lead nitrate orcarbonate. It is used in making flint glass, in glazing earthenware,in making red lead minium, etc. Called also massicot.
A small spot, shaped like a half-moon or crescent; as, thelunulet on the wings of many insects.
A kind of feldspar commonly showing a beautiful play of colors,and hence much used for ornamental purposes. The finest specimenscome from Labrador. See Feldspar.
A little moon or satellite. [Obs.] Bp. Hall.
Same as Lamellibranchia.
Linguadental.
The act or process luxuriating.
A small lion, especially one of several borne in the same coatof arms.

In a leering manner.
The lateral movement of a ship to the leeward of her course;drift.

To swallow or eat greedily; to devour; hence, to swallow up.[Obs.]Too far off from great cities, which may hinder business; too nearthem, which lurcheth all provisions, and maketh everything dear.Bacon.
Bearing marks of labor and effort; elaborately wrought; noteasy or natural; as, labored poetry; a labored style.
Laggingly. [Prov. Eng.]
The person to whom a license is given.
See Lignin.

Of or pertaining to movement or locomotion. Locomotor ataxia,or Progressive locomotor ataxy (Med.), a disease of the spinal cordcharacterized by peculiar disturbances of gait, and difficulty incoördinating voluntary movements.
See Hypermetropia.
See Leucocythæmia.-- Leu*chæm"ic, a. [Written also leukæmia, leukæmic.]
One of the labial palpi of an insect. See Illust. under Labium.
Abiding the law; waiting for the operation of law for theenforcement of rights; also, abiding by the law; obedient to the law;as, law-abiding people.
To gather what harvesters have left behind; to glean. [Obs.]Dryden.
Given to lewdness. [Obs.]
The quality of being lucid; lucidity.
Lager beer.
A diarrhea, in which the food is discharged imperfectlydigested, or with but little change. Dunglison.
A smooth kind of cartridge paper used for making cards. Knight.
One who levees. Cartwright.
The pitching or tossing of a vessel which results in thestraining of timbers and rigging.
A variety of black limestone, often polished for ornamentalpurposes.
One who takes up food or liquid with his tongue.
Separated by leads, as the lines of a page.
To legitimate.

A latitudinarian system or condition; freedom of opinion inmatters pertaining to religious belief.Fierce sectarianism bred fierce latitudinarianism. De Quincey.He [Ammonius Saccas] plunged into the wildest latitudinarianism ofopinion. J. S. Harford.
of Lock. Chaucer.

A roofed open gallery. It differs from a veranda in being morearchitectural, and in forming more decidedly a part of the mainedifice to which it is attached; from a porch, in being intended notfor entrance but for an out-of-door sitting-room.
Capable of being melted.
Turning or twisting the plane of polarization towards the left,as levulose, levotartaric acid, etc. [Written also lævogyrate.]
Full of light; bright. [R.] "Lightful presence." Marston.
One skilled in breaking and extracting stone in the bladder.
A limulus.
Having lungs, or breathing organs similar to lungs.
With loudness; loudly.To speak loud in public assemblies. Addison.

A very fine linen (or sometimes cotton) fabric with a ratheropen texture. Lawn is used for the sleeves of a bishop's officialdress in the English Church, and, figuratively, stands for the officeitself.A saint in crape is twice in lawn. Pope.
See Louver.
A strong caustic alkaline solution of potassium salts, obtainedby leaching wood ashes. It is much used in making soap, etc.

Sugar of milk or milk sugar; a crystalline sugar present inmilk, and separable from the whey by evaporation and crystallization.It has a slightly sweet taste, is dextrorotary, and is much lesssoluble in water than either cane sugar or glucose. Formerly calledlactin.
Loaded; freighted; burdened; as, a laden vessel; a laden heart.Ah sinful nation, a people laden with iniquity. Is. i. 4.A ship laden with gold. Shak.
Ladylike; not rough; gentle. [Obs.] "Stroked with a ladiedland." Feltham.
Loose. [Obs.] Chaucer.
Of or pertaining to a larva.
A propagating by layers. Gardner.
One of the Lamellibranchia. Also used adjectively.
A kind of granite from Luxullian, Cornwall, characterized bythe presence of radiating groups of minute tourmaline crystals.

The act of pouring a liquid or liquor, usually wine, either onthe ground or on a victim in sacrifice, in honor of some deity; also,the wine or liquid thus poured out. Dryden.A heathen sacrifice or libation to the earth. Bacon.
Pertaining to, or characterized by, liberalism; as,liberalistic opinions.
See Lief. [Obs.] Chaucer.
of Lete. Chaucer.
The European garfish.
A chemist. [Obs.] Boyle.
Of or pertaining to the plague or contagious disorders.
Belonging to present times or those recent by comparison.
The quality or state of being loud.
The quality or state of being limpid.
The leatherback.

Hydrous sesquixoide of iron, an important ore of iron,occurring in stalactitic, mammillary, or earthy forms, of a darkbrown color, yellowish brown powder. It includes bog iron. Alsocalled brown hematite.
The office of a leader.
An order of insects, which includes the butterflies and moths.They have broad wings, covered with minute overlapping scales,usually brightly colored.
See Ledgment.
Language; speech; dialect. [Slang]
Resembling the capitulum of burdock; covered with forkedpoints.
In a lazy manner. Locke.
Having locks or tufts. [R.] Sherwood.
To lose. [Obs.]They would rather leese their friend than their jest. Lord Burleigh.
Sportive. [Obs.] -- Lu"di*bund*ness, n. [Obs.] Dr. H. More.
The art of healing; skill of a physician. [Archaic] Chaucer.
With love; affectionately.
See Lickerish.-- Lic"o*rous*ness, n. [Obs.] Herbert.
A labial palp.

A division of beetles, including a large number of species, inwhich the antennæ are very long. Most of them, while in the larvalstate, bore into the wood or beneath the bark of trees, and somespecies are very destructive to fruit and shade trees. See Appleborer, under Apple, and Locust beetle, under Locust.
The perceptive faculty concerned with the ability to rememberthe relative positions of places.
A mass of iron in a pasty condition gathered into a ball forthe tilt hammer or rolls. [Written also loup.]
A lustration or purification, especially the purification ofthe whole Roman people, which was made by the censors once in fiveyears. Hence: A period of five years.
Having light and active wings; volatile; fleeting. Shak.
Same as Loadstar.
A species of mica, of a lilac or rose-violet color, containinglithia. It usually occurs in masses consisting of small scales. SeeMica.
The left-hand side of a ship to one on board facing toward thebow; port; -- opposed to Ant: starboard.
Pertaining to, or designating, a complex organic acid, obtainedas a yellowish white gum by the oxidation of croconic acid.
Bulky; heavy. Arbuthnot.
See Likable.
An eager desire; a craving; a morbid appetite; an earnest wish;an aspiration.Put on my crown; I have immortal longings in me. Shak.
Having, in some respects, the nature of light; resemblinglight. Berkeley.
Laminate. Laminated arch (Arch.), a timber arch made of layersof bent planks secured by treenails.
A tenant under a lease.-- Lease"hold`ing, a. & n.
of Lay. Laid paper, paper marked with parallel lines or watermarks, as if ribbed, from parallel wires in the mold. It is calledblue laid, cream laid, etc., according to its color.
A lance. [Obs.]

One of the outlines, exterior features, or distinctive marks,of a body or figure, particularly of the face; feature; form; mark; -- usually in the plural. "The lineaments of the body." Locke."Lineaments in the character." Swift.Man he seems In all his lineaments. Milton.
Not laughing; without laughter.

A crested black monkey (Semnopithecus maurus) of Java.
Having long wings, or quills.
To loll. [Obs. or Prov.] Spenser.

An aromatic plant of the genus Lavandula (L. vera), common inthe south of Europe. It yields and oil used in medicine andperfumery. The Spike lavender (L. Spica) yields a coarser oil (oil ofspike), used in the arts.
Vagrant; wandering about.
Praise; fame; reputation. [Obs.] Spenser.Good conscience and good loos. Chaucer.
Of or pertaining to the lymphatics, or lymphoid tissue;lymphatic.
Strictness, or the doctrine of strictness, in conforming tolaw.
One who libels; one who institutes a suit in an ecclesiasticalor admiralty court. [Written also libellant.] Cranch.
A thin piece placed between two parts to hold or adjust them,fill a space, etc., ; a shim.
Possessing much land.
In a loquacious manner.

Crowned, or decked, with laurel. Chaucer.To strew the laureate hearse where Lycid lies. Milton.Soft on her lap her laureate son reclines. Pope.Poet laureate. (b) One who received an honorable degree in grammar,including poetry and rhetoric, at the English universities; -- socalled as being presented with a wreath of laurel. [Obs.] (b)Formerly, an officer of the king's household, whose business was tocompose an ode annually for the king's birthday, and other suitableoccasions; now, a poet officially distinguished by such honorarytitle, the office being a sinecure. Omitting a letter; composed of words not having a certainletter or letters; as, lipogrammatic writings.

Any one of several metameric alkaloids, C5H3N.(CH3)2, of thepyridine series, obtained from bone oil as liquids, and havingpeculiar pungent odors. These alkaloids are also called respectivelydimethyl pyridine, ethyl pyridine, etc.

One of the tribe or family of Levi; a descendant of Levi; esp.,one subordinate to the priests (who were of the same tribe) andemployed in various duties connected with the tabernacle first, andafterward the temple, such as the care of the building, bringing ofwood and other necessaries for the sacrifices, the music of theservices, etc.

One of a class of cellular, flowerless plants, (technicallycalled Lichenes), having no distinction of leaf and stem, usually ofscaly, expanded, frond-like forms, but sometimes erect or pendulousand variously branched. They derive their nourishment from the air,and generate by means of spores. The species are very widelydistributed, and form irregular spots or patches, usually of agreenish or yellowish color, upon rocks, trees, and various bodies,to which they adhere with great tenacity. They are often improperlycalled rock moss or tree moss.
Lowest.

Of or pertaining to a particular place, or to a definite regionor portion of space; restricted to one place or region; as, a localcustom.Gives to airy nothing A local habitation and a name. Shak.Local actions (Law), actions such as must be brought in a particularcounty, where the cause arises; -- distinguished from transitoryactions.-- Local affection (Med.), a disease or ailment confined to aparticular part or organ, and not directly affecting the system.-- Local attraction (Magnetism), an attraction near a compass,causing its needle to deviate from its proper direction, especiallyon shipboard.-- Local battery (Teleg.), the battery which actuates the recordinginstruments of a telegraphic station, as distinguished from thebattery furnishing a current for the line.-- Local circuit (Teleg.), the circuit of the local battery.-- Local color. (a) (Paint.) The color which belongs to an object,and is not caused by accidental influences, as of reflection, shadow,etc. (b) (Literature) Peculiarities of the place and its inhabitantswhere the scene of an action or story is laid.-- Local option, the right or obligation of determining by popularvote within certain districts, as in each county, city, or town,whether the sale of alcoholic beverages within the district shall beallowed.

A large carnivorous feline mammal (Felis leo), found inSouthern Asia and in most parts of Africa, distinct varietiesoccurring in the different countries. The adult male, in mostvarieties, has a thick mane of long shaggy hair that adds to hisapparent size, which is less than that of the largest tigers. Thelength, however, is sometimes eleven feet to the base of the tail.The color is a tawny yellow or yellowish brown; the mane is darker,and the terminal tuft of the tail is black. In one variety, calledthe maneless lion, the male has only a slight mane.

imp. & p. p. of Lend.

from Leap, to jump. Leaping house, a brothel. [Obs.] Shak.-- Leaping pole, a pole used in some games of leaping.-- Leaping spider (Zoöl.), a jumping spider; one of the Saltigradæ.

The state or quality of being lenient; mildness of temper ordisposition; gentleness of treatment; softness; tenderness; clemency;-- opposed to severity and rigor.His exceeding lenity disposes us to be somewhat too severe. Macaulay.
