People; a nation; a man. [Obs.] Piers Plowman. Bp. Gibson.
Loquacity.
A type of bridge for small spans in which the floor girders arerigidly secured at their extremities to supporting steel legs, driveninto the round as piling, or resting on mudsills.
Like a lubber; clumsy.A great lubberly boy. Shak.

An extinct order of Amphibia, including the typical genusLabyrinthodon, and many other allied forms, from the Carboniferous,Permian, and Triassic formations. By recent writers they are dividedinto two or more orders. See Stegocephala.

Producing, or tending to produce, languor; characterized bylanguor. [Obs. or Poetic]Whom late I left in languorous constraint. Spenser.To wile the length from languorous hours, and draw The sting frompain. Tennyson.

The fruit of a tree native to China (Nephelium Litchi). It isnutlike, having a rough but tender shell, containing an aromaticpulp, and a single large seed. In the dried fruit which is exportedthe pulp somewhat resembles a raisin in color and form. [Written alsolichi, and lychee.] -- lite. See -lith.
Quality of being liable; liability.
One of the inhabitants of the llanos of South America.
A lamellicorn insect.
Such as can be learned.
A muscle of the human body. [Obs.] Chaucer.
By leaps.
A European whitefish (Coregonus laveretus), found in themountain lakes of Sweden, Germany, and Switzerland.
Having a slender elongated form, like a lath; -- said of thefeldspar of certain igneous rocks, as diabase, as seen in microscopicsections.
The quality or state of being limber; flexibleness. Boyle.
Full of juice or succulence. Tennyson.How lush and lusty the grass looks! how green! Shak.
See Lopsided.
Libertarian principles or doctrines.
See Lecanoric.

The line traced by a point which varies its position accordingto some determinate law; the surface described by a point or linethat moves according to a given law. Plane locus, a locus that is astraight line, or a circle.-- Solid locus, a locus that is one of the conic sections.
A genus of elongated bivalve shells, allied to the mussels, andremarkable for their ability to bore holes for shelter, in solidlimestone, shells, etc. Called also Lithophagus.
A plain sprinkled with trees or underbrush; a glade. [Obs.]In a laund upon an hill of flowers. Chaucer.Through this laund anon the deer will come. Shak.
A solution of a medicinal substance in water; -- distinguishedfrom tincture and aqua.
Producing profit; gainful. [Obs.]
A sac containing small, calcareous concretions (otoliths). Theyare found in many Medusæ, and other invertebrates, and are supposedto be auditory organs.
Wood-destroying; -- said of certain insects.
A person skilled in logic. Bacon.Each fierce logician still expelling Locke. Pope.
Such as can be lighted.
Having a lyre-shaped shoulder girdle, as certain fishes.
Any one of various species of moths belonging to the familyLithosidæ. Many of them are beautifully colored.
Long-breathed; hence, tediously long in speaking; consumingmuch time; as, a long-winded talker.-- Long"-wind"ed*ness, n.A tedious, long-winded harangue. South.
See Langegaye. [Obs.]
The oxide of lithium; a strong alkaline caustic similar topotash and soda, but weaker. See Lithium. Lithia emerald. SeeHiddenite.
See Lamaism. [R.]

A tutelary deity; a deceased ancestor regarded as a protectorof the family. The domestic Lares were the tutelar deities of ahouse; household gods. Hence, Eng.: Hearth or dwelling house.Nor will she her dear Lar forget, Victorious by his benefit.Lovelace.The Lars and Lemures moan with midnight plaint. Milton.Looking backward in vain toward their Lares and lands. Longfellow.
See Lesbianism.
One who listens; a hearkener.
One who contends about words.
Bright; shining; luminous. " Good sparks and lustrous." Shak.-- Lus"trous*ly, adv.
The act, or occupation, of one who launders; washing andironing.

One of a family (Lemuridæ) of nocturnal mammals allied to themonkeys, but of small size, and having a sharp and foxlike muzzle,and large eyes. They feed upon birds, insects, and fruit, and aremostly natives of Madagascar and the neighboring islands, one genus(Galago) occurring in Africa. The slow lemur or kukang of the EastIndies is Nycticebus tardigradus. See Galago, Indris, and Colugo.
An owner of land.
Healthy; salubrious; normal; having a disposition to promotehealing; not noxious; as, laudable juices of the body; laudable pus.Arbuthnot.
Like a lance. [R.] Sir P. Sidney.

A mineral of a fine azure-blue color, usually in small roundedmasses. It is essentially a silicate of alumina, lime, and soda, withsome sodium sulphide, is often marked by yellow spots or veins ofsulphide of iron, and is much valued for ornamental work. Called alsolapis lazuli, and Armenian stone.
Work in which one part laps over another. Grew.
See Lory.
See 1st Loop.
Unnatural sexual relations between women.
Any one of several species of feline animals of the genusFelis, and subgenus Lynx. They have a short tail, and usually apencil of hair on the tip of the ears.
To let; to allow. [Obs.] Chaucer.
A lantern pinion or trundle wheel. See Lantern pinion (below).

A large, thick, clumsy, marine fish (Cyclopterus lumpus) ofEurope and America. The color is usually translucent sea green,sometimes purplish. It has a dorsal row of spiny tubercles, and threerows on each side, but has no scales. The ventral fins unite and forma ventral sucker for adhesion to stones and seaweeds. Called alsolumpsucker, cock-paddle, sea owl.
In the direction of length.
Not long ago; recently; as, he has lately arrived from Italy.
Existing or continuing a long while; enduring; as, a lastinggood or evil; a lasting color.
To trace on stone by the process of lithography so as totransfer the design to paper by printing; as, to lithograph a design;to lithograph a painting. See Lithography.
Lovely. [Obs.]

An Asiatic and North African shrub (Lawsonia inermis), withsmooth oval leaves, and fragrant white flowers. Henna is preparedfrom the leaves and twigs. In England the shrub is called Egyptianprivet, and in the West Indies, Jamaica mignonette.
The state of being lax; laxity.
An extensive plain with or without vegetation. [SpanishAmerica]
Same as 4th Lunge.
Dark and threatening; gloomy; sullen; as, lowering clouds orsky.
A tool for lifting loose sand from the mold; also, acontrivance attached to a cope, to hold the sand together when thecope is lifted.
One of the spaces between the septa in the Anthozoa.
Spun out, or extended, to great length; hence, long-winded;tedious.The longspun allegories fulsome grow, While the dull moral lies tooplain below. Addison.
Of or pertaining to the Lophobranchii.-- n.
An order of Crustacea, including Nebalia and allied forms.
Broad-ribbed.
A long-tailed monkey (Semnopithecus schislaceus), from themountainous districts of India.
Lawful. "Licit establishments." Carlyle.-- Lic"it*ly, adv.-- Lic"it*ness, n.
Texas; -- a nickname alluding to the single star on its coat ofarms, being the device used on its flag and seal when it was arepublic.
One who is deficient in understanding; a witless person. Shak.
To be lazy or idle. [Colloq.] Middleton.
Of or pertaining to Laodicea, a city in Phrygia Major; like theChristians of Laodicea; lukewarm in religion. Rev. iii. 14-16.
One who, or that which, lessens.His wife . . . is the lessener of his pain, and the augmenter of hispleasure. J. Rogers (1839).
Lusty; vigorous. [Obs.]
Pertaining to, or derived from, the locust; -- formerly used todesignate a supposed acid.
The state of being a low-churchman.

Pertaining to, or designating, an organic acid which isobtained from several varieties of lichen (Lecanora, Roccella, etc.),as a white, crystalline substance, and is called also orsellic, ordiorsellinic acid, lecanorin, etc.
One who lithographs; one who practices lithography.
In a lasting manner.
A single type, containing two or more letters; as, æ, Æ, fi,fl, ffl, etc. ; -- called also ligature.
Pertaining, or given, to swooning; fainting.
One who studies by night; also, one who produces lucubrations.

A member of the Church of England, in the time of Charles II.,who adopted more liberal notions in respect to the authority,government, and doctrines of the church than generally prevailed.They were called "men of latitude;" and upon this, men of narrowthoughts fastened upon them the name of latitudinarians. Bp. Burnet.

A "tear-bottle;" a narrow-necked vessel found in sepulchers ofthe ancient Romans; -- so called from a former notion that the tearsof the deceased person's friends were collected in it. Called alsolachrymal or lacrymal.
A sweet, light-colored species of wine, produced in theprovince of Estremadura, and so called as being shipped from Lisbon,in Portugal.
One of two oval bodies hanging from the interior walls of thebody in the Acanthocephala.
A white, crystalline substance obtained as an anhydride ofalanine, and regarded as an imido derivative of lactic acid.
Long. [Obs.] Pope.
A lenitive; an emollient.
A set of quadrilles of a certain arrangement. [Written alsolanciers.]

The state or quality of being lovely.If there is such a native loveliness in the sex as to make themvictorious when in the wrong, how resistless their power when theyare on the side of truth! Spectator.
Having the effect of loosening or opening the intestines, andrelieving from constipation; -- opposed to astringent.-- n. (Med.)
Having a loud voice; noisy; clamorous. Byron.
Same as Lithotriptist.
Extended in length; tiresome. [Obs.] Bp. Hall. Prior.-- Long"some*ness, n. [Obs.] Fuller.
One who passes his life on land; -- so called among seamen incontempt or ridicule.
The state or quality of being literal. Sir T. Browne.
Transportation; conveyance. [Obs.]
A yellow amorphous substance obtained from lac.

Any one numerous species of small brush-tongued parrots orlories, found mostly in Australia, New Guinea and the adjacentislands, with some forms in the East Indies. They are arboreal intheir habits and feed largely upon the honey of flowers. They belongto Trichoglossus, Loriculus, and several allied genera.
Inclined to delay; dilatory. [Obs.] "When a man is toolatered." Chaucer.

The seeds of flax, from which linseed oil is obtained. [Writtenalso lintseed.] Linseed cake, the solid mass or cake which remainswhen oil is expressed.-- Linseed meal, linseed cake reduced to powder.-- Linseed oil, oil obtained by pressure from flaxseed.
A private path or road; also, the wicket or hatch of a door.[Prov. Eng.]
As much as the lap can contain.
A shrub in the West Indies (Lagetta Iintearia); -- so calledfrom the lacelike layers of its inner bark.

Capable of being split into laminæ or thin plates, as mica;capable of being extended under pressure into a thin plate or strip.When a body can be readily extended in all directions under thehammer, it is said to be malleable; and when into fillets under therolling press, it is said to be laminable. Ure.
Lividity. Walpole.
latching.
The science of worship; history, doctrine, and interpretationof liturgies.
A genus of large percoid fishes, of which one species (LatesNiloticus) inhabits the Nile, and another (L. calcarifer
Pertaining to a lake. Sir W. Scott.
of Last, to endure, contracted from lasteth. [Obs.] Chaucer.
The cicada.
An old game in England, played by throwing pieces of wood at astake set in the ground. [Obs.] Shak.
The office of a librarian.
To cut off the claws and balls of, as of a dog's fore feet.Wright.

To make less; to reduce; to make smaller, or fewer; todiminish; to lower; to degrade; as, to lessen a kingdom, or apopulation; to lessen speed, rank, fortune.Charity . . . shall lessen his punishment. Calamy.St. Paul chose to magnify his office when ill men conspired to lessenit. Atterbury.
The act of literalizing; reduction to a literal meaning.
Of or pertaining to Lima, or to the inhabitants of Lima, inPeru.-- n.
A leguminous plant (Medicago sativa), having bluish purplecloverlike flowers, cultivated for fodder; -- called also alfalfa.[Written also lucerne.]
The state or quality of being low.
pl. of Louse.
The ketone of lauric acid.
A straw plaiting used for bonnets and hats, made from the strawof a particular kind of wheat, grown for the purpose in Tuscany,Italy; -- so called from Leghorn, the place of exportation.

A plant of the genus Allium (A. Porrum), having broadly linearsucculent leaves rising from a loose oblong cylindrical bulb. Theflavor is stronger than that of the common onion. Wild leek , inAmerica, a plant (Allium tricoccum) with a cluster of ovoid bulbs andlarge oblong elliptical leaves.

A movement (usually involuntary) of the muscles of the face,particularly of the lips, with a peculiar expression of the eyes,indicating merriment, satisfaction, or derision, and usually attendedby a sonorous and interrupted expulsion of air from the lungs. SeeLaugh, v. i.The act of laughter, which is a sweet contraction of the muscles ofthe face, and a pleasant agitation of the vocal organs, is notmerely, or totally within the jurisdiction of ourselves. Sir T.Browne.Archly the maiden smiled, and with eyes overrunning with laughter.Longfellow.
See Lagoon.

A line inclosing or forming the extremity of a piece of ground,or field of combat; hence, in the plural (lists), the ground or fieldinclosed for a race or combat. Chaucer.In measured lists to toss the weighty lance. Pope.To enter the lists, to accept a challenge, or engage in contest.
Like, or pertaining to, Lithodomus; lithophagous.
Like a lath; long and slender.A lathy horse, all legs and length. R. Browning.
An East Indian monkey (Semnopithecus femoralis).
One who favors greater freedom in political or religiousmatters; an opponent of the established systems; a reformer; inEnglish politics, a member of the Liberal party, so called. Cf. Whig.
To lay. [Obs.]
A leaflet.
A metallic element separated from ytterbium in 1907, by Urbainin Paris and by von Welsbach in Vienna. Symbol, Lu; at. wt. 174.0.
Inflammation of the lymphatic glands; -- called also lymphitis.
Same as Liter.
The use of pretentious words, language, or style.

Not visible or apparent; hidden; springs of action.The evils latent in the most promising contrivances are provided foras they arise. Burke.Latent buds (bot.), buds which remain undeveloped or dormant for along time, but may at length grow. Latent heat (Physics), thatquantity of heat which disappears or becomes concealed in a bodywhile producing some change in it other than rise of temperature, asfusion, evaporation, or expansion, the quantity being constant foreach particular body and for each species of change.-- Latent period. (a) (Med.) The regular time in which a disease issupposed to be existing without manifesting itself. (b) (Physiol.)One of the phases in a simple muscular contraction, in whichinvisible preparatory changes are taking place in the nerve andmuscle. (c) (Biol.) One of those periods or resting stages in thedevelopment of the ovum, in which development is arrested prior torenewed activity.
See Laryngeal.
See Lussheburgh. [Obs.]
Characterized by clearness or transparency; clear; as, a limpidstream.Springs which were clear, fresh, and limpid. Woodward.
See Lotus.
A combination of meat with vegetables, bread, etc., usuallystewed, sometimes baked; an olio.
A West Indian fish of the genus Ephippus, remarkable for itshigh dorsal fin and brilliant colors.
Somewhat large. [Colloq.]
The day of the annunciation of the Virgin Mary, March 25. SeeAnnunciation.
The state of being, or the act of making, stony.
A mineral, of a white color and vitreous luster. It is ahydrous silicate of alumina and lime. Exposed to the air, it loseswater, becomes opaque, and crumbles. [Written also laumonite.]
Thin and flat; scalelike; lamellar.
See Legislatature, below.
A learned man; a man acquainted with literature; -- chieflyused in the plural.Now we are to consider that our bright ideal of a literatus maychance to be maimed. De Quincey.
Of or pertaining to Lethe; resembling in effect the water ofLethe. Milton. Barrow.
A medicine to check the secretion of milk, or to dispel asupposed accumulation of milk in any part of the body.
Like a lump; inert; gross; heavy; dull; spiritless. " Lumpish,heavy, melancholy." Shak.-- Lump"ish*ly, adv.-- Lump"ish*ness, n.
The capelin.
The state or quality of being lofty.
Any crime committed against the sovereign power.
Formed or uttered by the joint use of the tongue and teeth, orrather that part of the gum just above the front teeth; dentolingual,as the letters d and t.
A horizontal member spanning an opening, and carrying thesuperincumbent weight by means of its strength in resisting crosswisefracture.
An open box car used on railroads. Compare Lorry.
A rowdy street loafer; a rowdyish or noisy ill-bred fellow; --variously applied, as to a street blackguard, a street Arab, a youthgiven to horse-play, etc. [Australia & Eng.] -- a.
Affection; kind regard.The only two bands of good will, loveliness and lovingness. Sir. P.Sidney.
Land which is low with respect to the neighboring country; alow or level country; -- opposed to highland. The Lowlands, Belgiumand Holland; the Netherlands; also, the southern part of Scotland.
See Lignin.
The state, condition, or quality, of being light or not heavy;buoyancy; levity; fickleness; delicacy; grace.
A kind of precious stone.The third row a ligure, an agate, and an amethyst. Ex. xxviii. 19.
Detrimental. [Obs.] Bp. Hall.
A substance characterizing wood cells and differing fromcellulose in its conduct with certain chemical reagents.
Anything made of wool. [Obs.] Bacon.
Divination by means of stones.

To determine by agreement or by litigation the precise amountof (indebtedness); or, where there is an indebtedness to more thanone person, to determine the precise amount of (each indebtedness);to make the amount of (an indebtedness); clear and certain.A debt or demand is liquidated whenever the amount due is agreed onby the parties, or fixed by the operation of law. 15 Ga. Rep. 821.If our epistolary accounts were fairly liquidated, I believe youwould be brought in considerable debtor. Chesterfield.
Free from loss. [Obs.] Milton.
Porcelain impressed with figures which are made distinct bytransmitted light, -- as when hung in a window, or used as a lampshade.
Having the power of retaining the breath for a long time; long-winded.
To bark as a dog. [Obs.]
A painter of landscapes.
Laudableness; praiseworthiness.
See Legitimist.
In a lucky manner; by good fortune; fortunately; -- used in agood sense; as, they luckily escaped injury.
Lasting or continuing through life. Tennyson.
One employed in lumbering, cutting, and getting logs from theforest for lumber; a lumberman. [U.S.]Lumberers have a notion that he (the woodpecker) is harmful totimber. Lowell.
A little lip.
Leprose.-- Lep"rous*ly, adv.-- Lep"rous*ness, n.
Goods sunk in the sea, with a buoy attached in order that theymay be found again. See Jetsam and Flotsam. [Written also lagan.]Blackstone.
A youth woman; a girl; a sweetheart.
The quality of being lowminded; meanness; baseness.
A fieldwork consisting of two faces, forming a salient angle,and two parallel flanks. See Bastion.
Having the appearance of being labiate; -- said of certainpolypetalous corollas.

A rare element of the group of the earth metals, allied toaluminium. It occurs in certain rare minerals, as cerite, gadolinite,orthite, etc., and was so named from the difficulty of separating itfrom cerium, didymium, and other rare elements with which it isusually associated. Atomic weight 138.5. Symbol La. [Formerly writtenalso lanthanium.]
See 1st Lar.
A colorless corpuscle, as one of the white blood corpuscles, orthose found in lymph, marrow of hone, connective tissue, etc.
Belonging to, or covered with, lichens. Tennyson.

To turn the head of a vessel toward the wind; to sail nearerthe wind; to turn the tiller so as to make the vessel sail nearer thewind. To luff round, or To luff alee, to make the extreme of thismovement, for the purpose of throwing the ship's head into the wind.
A yellow coloring matter, soluble in ether, contained in thesmall round fat drops in the retinal epithelium cells. It is bestobtained from the eyes of frogs.

Like bricks; of the color of red bricks. Lateritious sediment(Med.), a sediment in urine resembling brick dust, observed after thecrises of fevers, and at the termination of gouty paroxysms. Itusually consists of uric acid or urates with some coloring matter.
Like a lobule; pertaining to a lobule or lobules.
Lengthwise.
The latex of certain plants. See Latex.
An acid amide derived from lactic acid, and obtained as a whitecrystalline substance having a neutral reaction. It is metameric withalanine.
The state or quality of being livid.
Of or pertaining to the monitorial system of instructionfollowed by Joseph Lancaster, of England, in which advanced pupils ina school teach pupils below them.
The lower or apparently anterior petal of an orchidaceousflower, often of a very curious shape.
In a small quantity or degree; not much; slightly; somewhat; --often with a preceding it. " The poor sleep little." Otway.
Such as can be liked; such as to attract liking; as, a likableperson. Thackeray.
Death.[Obs.] Shak.
One who makes or enacts a law or system of laws; a legislator.
One who lectures; an assistant preacher.
A larder. [Obs.]
A genus of maritime herbs (Plumbago). P. Europæa has lead-colored spots on the leaves, and nearly lead-colored flowers.
A torch made of tow and pitch, or the like. Shak.
A spurious coin of light weight imported into England fromLuxemburg, or Lussheburgh, as it was formerly called. [Obs.]God wot, no Lussheburghes payen ye. Chaucer.
A genus consisting of two species of tall trees having star-shaped leaves, and woody burlike fruit. Liquidambar styraciflua isthe North American sweet qum, and L. Orientalis is found in AsiaMinor.
Having (such or so many) legs; -- used in composition; as, along-legged man; a two-legged animal.
A muscle that serves to raise some part, as the lip or theeyelid.

An alliance or combination of two or more nations, parties, orpersons, for the accomplishment of a purpose which requires acontinued course of action, as for mutual defense, or for furtheranceof commercial, religious, or political interests, etc.And let there be 'Twixt us and them no league, nor amity. Denham.
Capable of being changed from a solid to a liquid state.
Same as Laplander. Cf. Lapps.
Any thick lump, mass, or cake; especially, a large regularlyshaped or molded mass, as of bread, sugar, or cake. Bacon. Loafsugar, refined sugar that has been formed into a conical loaf in amold.
Going to law; litigation. Holinshed.
A plastic operation for making a new lip, or for replacing alost tissue of a lip.
A stone that becomes phosphoric by heat.
Lying down; -- used of beasts of the chase, as couchant is ofbeasts of prey.
A diarrhea or flux. [Obs.] Holland.
of Leap. [Obs.]And, laughing, lope into a tree. Spenser.
A liquid or semiliquid preparation of a consistence thinnerthan an ointment, applied to the skin by friction, esp. one used as asedative or a stimulant.
To lethargize. [Obs.] Shak.
A plunderer.
An order of teleostean fishes, having the gills arranged intufts on the branchial arches, as the Hippocampus and pipefishes.
. A color of cloth formerly made in Lincoln, England; the clothitself.
Literal meaning. [Obs.] Sir T. Browne.
One who litigates.
A key used to raise, or throw back, the latch of a door, esp. anight latch.

A sort of riddle in which it is required to discover a chosenword from various combinations of its letters, or of some of itsletters, which form other words; -- thus, to discover the chosen wordchatter form cat, hat, rat, hate, rate, etc. B. Jonson.
A tin-white arsenide of iron, isomorphous with arsenopyrite.
One who plays on a lute.
A loch or lake; -- so spelt in Ireland.
Light in weight, as a coin; specif., applied to a man or animalwho is a lightweight.
Disease, especially of a contagious kind. Lues venerea,syphilis; -- called also simply lues.
A little lady; -- applied by the writers of Queen Elizabeth'stime, in the abbreviated form Lakin, to the Virgin Mary.
Cloudy; gloomy; lowering; as, a lowery sky; lowery weather.
To please; -- chiefly used impersonally. [Obs.] " Sith itlyketh you." Chaucer.

A locomotive engine; a self-propelling wheel carriage,especially one which bears a steam boiler and one or more steamengines which communicate motion to the wheels and thus propel thecarriage, -- used to convey goods or passengers, or to draw wagons,railroad cars, etc. See Illustration in Appendix. Consolidationlocomotive, a locomotive having four pairs of connected drivers.-- Locomotive car, a locomotive and a car combined in one vehicle; adummy engine. [U.S.] -- Locomotive engine. Same as Locomotive, above.-- Mogul locomotive. See Mogul.

The capital city of Peru, in South America. Lima bean. (Bot.)(a) A variety of climbing or pole bean (Phaseolus lunatus), which hasvery large flattish seeds. (b) The seed of this plant, much used forfood.-- Lima wood (Bot.), the beautiful dark wood of the South Americantree Cæsalpinia echinata.
Same as Loadsman. [Obs.]
See Lickerish, Lickerishness. Chaucer.

Any young insect from the time that it hatches from the egguntil it becomes a pupa, or chrysalis. During this time it usuallymolts several times, and may change its form or color each time. Thelarvæ of many insects are much like the adults in form and habits,but have no trace of wings, the rudimentary wings appearing only inthe pupa stage. In other groups of insects the larvæ are totallyunlike the parents in structure and habits, and are calledcaterpillars, grubs, maggots, etc.
Laid a side; cast-off.
A tonguelike process or part.
The modification of an articulation by contraction of the lipopening.
The state or quality of being legible.
Liquor. [Obs.] Chaucer.

A sirupy variety of sugar, rarely obtained crystallized,occurring widely in honey, ripe fruits, etc., and hence called alsofruit sugar. It is called levulose, because it rotates the plane ofpolarization to the left. [Written also lævulose.]C6H12O6.

An extensive series of strata, principally developed in theRocky Mountain region, as in the Laramie Mountains, and formerlysupposed to be of the Tertiary age, but now generally regarded asCretaceous, or of intermediate and transitional character. Itcontains beds of lignite, often valuable for coal, and is hence alsocalled the lignitic group. See Chart of Geology.
A white, crystalline substance, obtained from also, byextension, any similar substance.
Lightening. [R.]
Labiate.
Belonging to, or resembling, a very large natural order ofplants (Leguminosæ), which bear legumes, including peas, beans,clover, locust trees, acacias, and mimosas.
See Lich wake, under Lich.

A long, slender rope made of hemp or strips of hide, esp. onewith a noose; -- used as a lasso for catching cattle, horses, etc.,and for picketing a horse so that he can graze without wandering.[Mexico & Western U.S.]
Luxury. [Obs.] Shenstone. Édition de luxe (. Etym: [F.](Printing) A sumptuous edition as regards paper, illustrations,binding, etc.
Likelihood. [Obs.] South.
See Loch, a medicine.
Of or pertaining to laryngology.
With limitation.
The state, condition, or quality, of being loose; as, thelooseness of a cord; looseness of style; looseness of morals or ofprinciples.
Verbal legerdemain; a playing with words. [R.] Coleridge.
Of or pertaining to the Lucernarida.-- n.
Pertaining to, or obtained from, hops; specifically,designating an acid obtained by the decomposition of lupulin.
The albumin present on milk, apparently identical with ordinaryserum albumin. It is distinct from the casein of milk.
Lips. [Obs. & R.] Shak.
A person that plays on the lute. Johnson.
A lodge; a habitation. [Obs.] Chaucer.
A pod dehiscent into two pieces or valves, and having the seedattached at one suture, as that of the pea.
Luminous. [R.]
A strong, buoyant boat especially designed for saving the livesof shipwrecked people.
An order of teleostean fishes, including the Anabas, orclimbing perch, and other allied fishes.
A genus of fungi, remarkable for the great quantity of spores,forming a fine dust, which is thrown out like smoke when the plant iscompressed or burst; puffball.

A net for leading fish into a pound, weir, etc. ; also, a lineof gut, to which the snell of a fly hook is attached.(i) (Mining) A branch or small vein, not important in itself, butindicating the proximity of a better one.
Of or pertaining to a lobe; characterized by, or like, a lobeor lobes.
A supposed salt of lampic acid. [Obs.]
In a luciferous manner.
An alkaloid found in several species of lupine (Lupinus luteus,L. albus, etc.), and extracted as a bitter crystalline substance.
An herb, the wall pellitory. See Pellitory.
The six-legged young, or larva, of certain mites; -- sometimesused as a generic name. See Harvest mite, under Harvest.

In most of the States and Territories of the United States, aday, usually the first Monday of September, set aside as a legalholiday, in honor of, or in the interest of, workingmen as a class.Also, a similar holiday in Canada, Australia, etc.
A lunar distance.
A rocking or balanced stone. Gwill.

A real or apparent libratory motion, like that of a balancebefore coming to rest. Libration of the moon, any one of those smallperiodical changes in the position of the moon's surface relativelyto the earth, in consequence of which narrow portions at oppositelimbs become visible or invisible alternately. It receives differentnames according to the manner in which it takes place; as: (a)Libration in longitude, that which, depending on the place of themoon in its elliptic orbit, causes small portions near the easternand western borders alternately to appear and disappear each month.(b) Libration in latitude, that which depends on the varying positionof the moon's axis in respect to the spectator, causing the alternateappearance and disappearance of either pole. (c) Diurnal orparallactic libration, that which brings into view on the upper limb,at rising and setting, some parts not in the average visiblehemisphere.
